The code can handle both radial and nonradial oscillations, and it includes options for dealing with truncated (envelope) models. The numerical problem is formulated as solving a system of equations with boundary conditions, and the code uses two techniques for solving these equations: a shooting method and a relaxation technique. The document also discusses the use of a standard secant technique for finding eigenvalues and the option to scan through a given interval in the parameter space to look for changes of sign of the discriminant. The code includes two techniques for improving the precision of the computed frequencies: a variational principle and Richardson extrapolation. The document also discusses the importance of distinguishing between precision and accuracy in the computation of stellar oscillation frequencies.

Leo I is a dwarf spheroidal galaxy (dSph) with unique characteristics among local group galaxies. It has a young stellar population, lacking a conspicuous old population and having a larger fraction of intermediate-age and young population compared to other dSPh galaxies. Star formation seems to have continued until almost the present time, with no intense, distinct bursts of star formation. The analysis of the data using synthetic command lines (CMDs) will provide quantitative information about the strength of star formation at different epochs. Further observations are needed to characterize the variable-star population in Leo I, search for rr Lyrae variable stars, and determine whether the horizontal branch (HB) is missing in the outer parts of Leo I. Answering these questions is important for understanding the formation and evolution of Leo I and the epoch of galaxy formation and the evolution of galaxies of different morphological types. The determination of the strength of star formation in Leo I at different epochs is important for assessing whether it is possible that during intervals of high star formation activity, Leo I would have been as bright as the faint blue galaxies observed at intermediate redshift. The duration of such a major event of star formation may be important in explaining the number counts of faint blue galaxies. The text also thanks various individuals and organizations for their contributions and support.

Continuous variable quantum key distribution (CVQKD) has made significant theoretical and experimental strides, with practical implementation systems achieving secure communication over tens of kilometers. The security of these systems, which use prepare-and-measure (PM) implementation, has been confirmed through the security analysis of equivalent entanglement-based (EB) schemes. However, traditional security analysis of the EB scheme in CVQKD only considers the signal beam and not the local oscillator (LO), an auxiliary light beam used for phase reference in balanced homodyne detection. This leaves security loopholes, as LO is within Eve's manipulation domain. The necessity of monitoring LO intensity for security proofs in discrete QKD protocols has been discussed, and the excess noise caused by imperfect subtraction of the balanced homodyne detector in the presence of LO intensity fluctuations has been noted and quantified. In practical CVQKD implementation, shot noise scaling with LO power, measured before key distribution, is assumed to remain constant, with pulses exhibiting large LO intensity fluctuations being discarded. This approach, however, gives Eve an advantage in exploiting LO intensity fluctuations. This paper discusses Bob's measurements under LO intensity fluctuations, proposes an attacking scheme that exploits this fluctuation, and calculates the secret key rate with and without Bob monitoring the LO for reverse and direct reconciliation protocols. The analysis reveals that LO intensity fluctuations could compromise secret keys if Bob does not scale his measurements with instantaneous LO intensity values. The paper also briefly discusses accurate LO intensity monitoring to ensure the security of practical CVQKD implementation.

Majorana fermions (MFs) are real solutions of the Dirac equation and are their own antiparticles. Although originally proposed as a model for neutrinos, MFs have been predicted to occur as quasiparticle bound states in engineered condensed matter systems. These particles obey non-Abelian statistics, making them promising for decoherence-free quantum computation and quantum information processing. Over the past few years, the search for MFs has focused on topological superconductors, and various platforms including topological insulators, semiconductor nanowires, and atomic chains have been proposed to support Majorana states based on the superconducting proximity effect. However, observing the unique Majorana signatures experimentally is still a challenging task. MFs are predicted to appear in tunneling spectroscopy experiments as characteristic zero-bias peaks (ZBPs). Although ZBPs have been observed in semiconductor nanowires and are interpreted as the signatures of MFs, these results cannot serve as definitive evidence for the existence of MFs in condensed matter systems. Experimentally distinguishing Majorana bound states from conventional fermionic subgap states is a major challenge. The text proposes an alternative all-optical scheme to detect MFs using a hybrid quantum dot-nanomechanical resonator system. This scheme avoids introducing signals that could disturb the detection of MFs by eliminating direct contact between MFs and the hybrid quantum dot-nanomechanical resonator system. The interaction between MFs in iron chains and the quantum dot in the hybrid quantum dot-nanomechanical resonator system is mainly due to dipole-dipole interaction, and the distance between the two systems can be adjusted by several tens of nanometers, ensuring that the tunneling between the quantum dot and MFs can be neglected safely. The quantum dot is considered as a two-level system, and once MFs appear in the ends of iron chains and couple to the quantum dot, the Majorana signature will be carried out via the coherent optical spectrum of the quantum dot. The change in the coherent optical spectrum serves as another potential evidence for MFs in the iron chains. This optical scheme provides a new method for the detection of MFs, which is very different from the zero-bias peak in the tunneling experiments.

In many fields of physics, there is ongoing work to infer macroscopic properties of physical systems from their microscopic description, with significant changes in properties occurring at phase transitions which often involve symmetry breaking. The theory of phase transitions was formulated by Landau and later devised from microscopic principles using the renormalization group. Identifying phases can be done through an order parameter, which is zero in the disordered phase and nonzero in the ordered phase. However, there are states of matter where an order parameter can only be defined in a complicated non-local way, such as in topological states like topological insulators, quantum spin hall states, or quantum spin liquids. Machine learning techniques, particularly neural networks, have been used to develop new methods for identifying parameters capable of describing phase transitions. These techniques have been successful in image classification, speech recognition, natural language understanding, and predicting from high-dimensional data, and have begun to be employed in physics for tasks such as reproducing Monte Carlo-sampled states of the Ising model and identifying phase transitions. Unsupervised learning algorithms, which can find structure in unlabeled data and classify data into clusters, have been used to reproduce Monte Carlo-sampled states of the Ising model and find phase transitions using principal component analysis. Variational autoencoders, which impose restrictions on the distribution of latent variables, have shown promising results in encoding and reconstructing data in the field of computer vision. In this work, unsupervised learning is used to determine phase transitions without any information about the microscopic theory or the order parameter, and it is found that the reconstruction is more accurate in the ordered phase, suggesting the use of the reconstruction error as a universal identifier for phase transitions.

1. This paper is motivated by a result from Berestycki et al. about the Laplacian perturbed by a divergence-free drift in dimensions n ≥ 3.
2. The authors consider the principal eigenvalue of a fractional Laplacian with a drift that is divergence-free and of zero exterior Dirichlet condition.
3. They define the set of non-trivial first integrals in a Sobolev space equipped with a norm coming from the Dirichlet form of the fractional Laplacian.
4. The main difficulty in their development is the roughness and non-locality of the fractional Laplacian, which prevent a direct application of differential calculus.
5. The authors use conditioning, approximation techniques for flows, and properties of the Green function and heat kernel of gradient perturbations of the fractional Laplacian to define and study the principal eigen-pair.
6. They prove that the principal eigenvalue remains bounded as the domain becomes large if and only if there exists a non-trivial first integral of the drift.
7. The authors also discuss the implications of their results in the context of a compact, connected Riemannian manifold.
8. They show that the estimates of the Green function and transition density of the fractional Laplacian for the Dirichlet problem on a bounded domain are determined by the restriction of the drift to the domain.
9. The authors prove that the corresponding Green's and transition operators are compact, which allows them to define the principal eigen-pair via the Krein-Rutman theorem.
10. They prove that the domains of the classical Laplacian and the fractional Laplacian with Dirichlet conditions coincide.

<summary> The unification scheme of Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) suggests that the difference between Type 1 and Type 2 AGN is due to angle-dependent circumnuclear obscuration of the accretion disk and broad-line region. This obscuring medium, called the "dust torus," is optically and geometrically thick, extending from sub-parsec to several tens of parsecs. The dust in the torus absorbs incident UV/optical radiation and re-emits it in the infrared. Type 1 AGN show more emission in the near-IR than Type 2 AGN for the same intrinsic luminosity, which is consistent with the face-on view of the torus exposing the innermost hot dust to the observer in Type 1 AGN and the edge-on view being blocked by internal obscuration in Type 2 AGN. The anisotropy in the infrared has implications for forming isotropic AGN samples based on infrared fluxes and distinguishing torus models with smoothly distributed dust from those with dust arranged in clouds. High spatial resolution observations or using high luminosity objects can help mitigate the problem of host galaxy contribution to the infrared emission. This paper aims to quantify the wavelength dependence of the anisotropy of AGN emission in the infrared using a nearly isotropically selected and complete sample of quasars and radio galaxies with hidden quasars. The analysis is improved by using host-galaxy subtraction for the radio galaxies and clumpy torus models for interpretation. The paper discusses the results by comparing them to previous infrared anisotropy estimates in literature. The sample comprises 3CRR radio galaxies and quasars, and the data used include mid-IR photometry and spectroscopy obtained using the Spitzer Space Telescope. Additional corrections are applied to the radio galaxy data before averaging to isolate the emission coming from the active nucleus. The paper also discusses the scenarios that can lead to the observed anisotropy in radio galaxies and quasars, including extinction by a cold dust screen and absorption and emission in a warm dusty medium. </summary>

The main laws of quantum mechanics prohibit the perfect cloning of quantum states, but approximate copying is possible with quantum cloning machines (QCMs) that can produce identical or non-identical copies, with quality that can be state-dependent or universal. One possible application of QCMs is eavesdropping on a quantum channel, where the goal is to copy part of the quantum state, and the design of the QCM depends on the specific eavesdropping strategy.

The nature of dark matter remains uncertain, with the possibility of a significant baryonic component. Some authors propose that cold, self-gravitating molecular clouds could constitute a major component of dark matter, and this hypothesis can be tested by comparing gamma-ray emission predictions with high-quality data from the Compton Gamma Ray Observatory. However, previous investigations have neglected important effects such as self-shielding and cascade phenomena, which could be relevant to the observed excess galactic flux above 1 GeV.

The extinction curve describes how extinction, caused by dust grains in the interstellar medium, changes with wavelength. Knowledge of the extinction curve is necessary for dereddening magnitudes and colors of astronomical objects and understanding the physical properties of dust grains. Cardelli, Clayton, and Mathis (CCM) derived a mean extinction law that depends on one parameter, representing a one-parameter family of curves that represents the UV to IR extinction law. This law allows for the determination of extinction in one spectral region based on the extinction in a different spectral region, given the knowledge of the parameter. The CCM law has been widely used to study extinction and deredden data.

On October 9, 2006, K. Itagaki discovered a possible supernova (SN) in UGC 4904, which was later classified as Type Ib SN 2006jc. The SN was discovered after its peak, but an upper limit of its magnitude was obtained 208 days before discovery. An optical transient was reported in 2004 close to the SN's position, suggesting a luminous blue variable (LBV)-like event. The spatial coincidence between the LBV-like event and SN 2006jc led to follow-up observations in various wavebands, including X-ray, ultra-violet, optical, infrared, and radio. Spectroscopic observations revealed broad features and strong narrow emission lines, indicating an ongoing dust formation. The bolometric luminosity of SN 2006jc was constructed from the integration of UV, optical, and IR photometries, and the estimated peak bolometric magnitude was found to be as bright as SN 2006aj. The spherical explosion models with higher explosion energies yielded too much nickel-56, but assuming aspherical fallback in high-energy models could decrease nickel-56 and increase the central remnant mass.

In the 1970s, many-body theory flourished, with many-body effects on x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra from deep core levels in metals receiving significant attention. These effects included singularities near edges in absorption and emission spectra, and shake-up effects in XPS peaks from core levels, which can be attributed to the excitation of plasmons in the metal. In the case of graphene, the 2D character of the system results in 2D plasmons with a different dispersion than in ordinary 3D metallic systems, making quantitative interpretation of graphene core-hole spectra challenging. The present work aims to provide tools for calculating graphene core-hole spectra, and demonstrates the importance of making a full calculation of these spectra instead of relying on Doniach and Sunji fitting of the peaks.

The text discusses the use of the Moran process, a mathematical model used to simulate the evolution of two genotypes within a population, in the context of evolutionary game theory. The authors argue that while the Moran process is typically used with symmetric mutation probabilities and linear interaction functions, real-world systems may exhibit asymmetric mutation probabilities and nonlinear interaction effects. They derive the Fokker-Planck equation, which describes the dynamics of the system in the limit of large population sizes, and use it to analyze the impact of asymmetric mutation probabilities and nonlinear interaction functions on the system's behavior. The authors find that these factors can lead to the emergence of new stable points and the shifting of existing stable points, and conclude that such complex evolutionary dynamics may be relevant in real biological systems.

A hypergeometric system is a system of differential equations with hypergeometric functions as solutions. It is determined by a matrix and a complex parameter vector. These systems are also known as GKZ systems and occur naturally in mathematics and physics, including the study of roots of polynomials, Picard-Fuchs equations for the variation of Hodge structure of Calabi-Yau toric hypersurfaces, and generating functions for intersection numbers on moduli spaces of curves. The rank of a hypergeometric system is the dimension of its solution space at a nonsingular point. In this article, the authors provide a combinatorial formula for the rank of a hypergeometric system in terms of certain lattice translates determined by the matrix and a vector. This computation yields a geometric stratification of the parameter space that refines its stratification by the rank of the hypergeometric system. The relationship between the rank of the hypergeometric system and the lattice translates is made precise using Euler Koszul homology. The exceptional arrangement, which is a subspace arrangement in the parameter space given by translates of linear subspaces that are generated by the faces of the cone determined by the matrix, plays a key role in this relationship. The rank of the hypergeometric system is constant on each ranking slab, which is a stratum in the coarsest stratification of the exceptional arrangement that respects certain arrangements determined by the quasidegrees of a weakly toric module. The ranking slab stratification of the parameter space refines its rank stratification.

<summary> Quantum algorithms, particularly Grover's algorithm, perform more efficiently than classical counterparts due to quantum superposition and interference. Grover's algorithm can search an unsorted database with a quadratic advantage over classical methods. The algorithm has been realized in various physical systems, with superconducting qubit-cavity QED being an attractive approach. Recently, dicarlo et al. demonstrated the implementation of two-qubit Grover and Deutsch-Jozsa algorithms and preparation and measurement of three-qubit entanglement using superconducting qubits. This work aims to implement a three-qubit Grover search using four-level squids in cavity-QED. The authors propose a three-qubit phase gate to reduce the number of quantum gates required for the algorithm's realization. The three-qubit Grover search is probabilistic, and multiple iterations are needed to achieve high success probability. The proposed scheme uses resonant and off-resonant interactions and does not require adjustment of squid level spacing, reducing decoherence. The authors also consider the effects of spontaneous decay and cavity decay during the implementation of Grover's iterations.
</summary>

<summary>

1. Networks of single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) are emerging as novel electronic materials, creating a need for accurate determination of their electrical properties.
2. SWCNT networks can be viewed as a two-dimensional network of conducting one-dimensional rods with large dimension ratio, leading to networks with randomly distributed barriers for electrical transport.
3. The junction resistance in SWCNT networks dominates the overall resistance, exhibiting percolation behavior with nonlinear thickness dependence.
4. For SWCNT networks with thickness in the tens of nanometers, the conductance through metallic tubes dominates, leading to metallic behavior of the overall resistance.
5. Frequency- and electric-field dependent conductivity have been investigated for individual SWCNTs and some types of SWCNT networks.
6. There is a lack of investigation on the correlation between the onset frequency and the length scale determined from nonlinear transport in SWCNT networks.
7. Understanding the frequency and electric field dependent conductivity of SWCNT networks is important for applications such as high-speed transistors, transparent shielding materials, and interconnects in circuits.
8. The frequency- and electric-field dependent conductivity investigation of different network densities is helpful to build a comprehensive understanding of the electrical transport properties of SWCNT networks.
9. SWCNT networks on polyethylene terephthalate substrate were prepared by the spraying method, and the frequency and electric field dependent conductivity were investigated.
10. The onset frequency extracted from the frequency dependence measurement increases with the film thickness, while the length scale extracted from the electric field dependent measurement decreases at the same time.

</summary>

<summary>

1. Soft X-ray transients (SXRTs) in outburst share similarities with persistent low-mass X-ray binaries containing a neutron star (LMXRBs).
2. The large variations in accretion rate in SXRTs allow for the study of regimes inaccessible to LMXRBs.
3. The powering mechanism of SXRTs in the quiescent state is unclear, but a possibility is that a millisecond radio pulsar (MSP) turns on.
4. AQL X-1 is the most active SXRT known, with over 30 X-ray and/or optical outbursts, and a K1V variable star companion with a 19-hour orbital period.
5. The outbursts of AQL X-1 are characterized by a fast rise and slow decay, with type I X-ray bursts indicating the presence of a neutron star.
6. The X-ray spectrum of AQL X-1 changes from a soft blackbody to a power law with decreasing luminosity during the outburst decay.
7. BEPPOSAX observations of AQL X-1 allowed for the first detailed study of a SXRT outburst down to quiescence.
8. The steepening in the X-ray flux decrease of AQL X-1 has no clear parallel in low-mass X-ray transients containing black hole candidates.
9. The different outburst evolution of SXRTs and black hole transients is likely due to the different nature of the underlying objects.
10. The discovery of a nearly coherent modulation at 450 Hz during a type I X-ray burst in AQL X-1 suggests the possibility of accretion onto the neutron star surface even in the quiescent state, but this faces difficulties in explaining the observed quiescent luminosity and the steepening in the outburst decay.

</summary>

A quantum computer using qubits and quantum logical gates can perform certain algorithms much faster than classical computers, such as Shor's algorithm for factorizing numbers. Semiconductor quantum dots with controlled electron numbers are good candidates for realizing qubits, which can be encoded using an electron charge or spin. Spin qubits have longer decoherence times and can be manipulated using electron spin resonance and read out via currents in spin-polarized leads. Another concept for encoding qubits is based on the singlet-triplet states in a double quantum dot, which can be prepared and manipulated by electrical control of the exchange interactions. In a triangular geometry, three coherently coupled quantum dots can form a decoherence-free subspace that is immune to decoherence processes and can be controlled by purely electrical means, providing faster operations and more complex energy spectra. Recent experimental efforts have demonstrated coherent spin manipulations in a linear triple quantum dot system. The proposal by Divincenzo et al. to encode the qubit in a triangular triple quantum dot has been studied using an electric field to modify the exchange coupling and generate chiral or flux-penetrated states. The authors' idea is to use the fully electrical control of the symmetry of the triple quantum dot to encode and manipulate the qubit in the doublet subspace, and propose a new detection method called the doublet blockade effect, which manifests itself in currents for a special configuration of the local potential gates, and is fully compatible with purely electrical manipulations of the qubit. The dynamics of the qubit are studied, taking into account relaxation and decoherence processes due to coupling with the electrodes and leakage from the doublet subspace. The system is a triangular artificial molecule built of three coherently coupled quantum dots with a single electron spin on each dot, and the exchange interactions are described by an effective Heisenberg Hamiltonian with a Zeeman term for splitting by an external magnetic field. The exchange parameter can be calculated by Heitler-London and Hund-Mulliken methods for a defined confinement potential, and depends on the interdot distance, potential barrier, and magnetic field.

<summary>

1. Colloidal crystals have the potential to create novel materials through self-assembly, with unique optical properties that can generate iridescent colors and serve as a means to produce photonic crystals.
2. These crystals have a well-defined thermodynamic temperature, allowing them to be viewed as mesoscopic "model atoms" for studying condensed matter physics.
3. Recent advances have demonstrated tunable colors through control of lattice spacing with an external field and the ability to form various structures by tuning colloid-colloid interactions.
4. First-order ac electric fields can induce dipolar interactions between colloidal particles, leading to anisotropic interparticle potentials and exotic crystal structures.
5. External control of colloid-colloid interactions enables the observation of phase transitions and microscopic detail at the single-particle level, offering insights into long-standing problems in condensed matter, such as freezing.
6. The introduction of a rotating ac field results in in-plane attractions and repulsions above and below, potentially forming disc-like patterns in granular matter and crystalline structures in colloidal dispersions.
7. A coplanar rotating electric field can control lattice spacing within quasi-2d colloidal crystals by treating interparticle dipolar interactions as a circularly symmetric attraction.
8. Coarse-graining schemes have been developed to reduce the complexity of the description by integrating out smaller molecular and ionic species, leading to a one-component picture with effective colloid-colloid interactions.
9. The equilibrium behavior of the colloids in the original multi-component system can be faithfully reproduced using liquid state theory and computer simulation.
10. A simple numerical treatment can predict lattice spacing in the quasi 2d crystal from the electric field strength, combining experimental measurements and Monte Carlo simulations with a screened Coulomb repulsion plus dipolar attraction.

</summary>

Note: The summary is designed to provide a concise and accurate representation of the source document, focusing on the most important aspects and findings.

<summary> The Z Andromedae (Z And) binary system is composed of a cool giant star and a hot white dwarf, surrounded by nebulae that emit radiation across a wide frequency range. The system has experienced periodic outbursts, including a series of eruptions in 1984 and 1986. These outbursts may be the result of varying wind velocities and accretion rates, leading to the formation of an optical thick wind and the collision of stellar winds. The collision of winds creates shock fronts and affects the ionization and temperature of the system. The 1984-1986 outburst is notable for its double-peaked structure and low brightness, which may be the result of red giant pulsation and the collision of the white dwarf wind with ejected shells. The minimum between the two peaks is accompanied by a dip in the ionization parameter. The outburst did not reach its maximum luminosity due to the distortion of the wind network by the oncoming of the next shell. Broad lines and jets, which were not observed during the 1984-1986 outburst, are common in other symbiotic systems and are thought to originate from high-velocity matter accompanying outbursts and the presence of an accretion disk. The distance of the nebulae from the center of the system has been calculated in previous works by adjusting the continuum fluxes calculated by the models at the nebula to those observed at earth. The best fit to the data of the bremsstrahlung calculated from the nebulae downstream of the shock front gives the distance of the nebula from the center of the system at various points in time. The drop of the ionization parameter between November and December 1985 most probably derives from the sudden increase of the distance from the hot source, which is explained by the ejection of the next shell in the red giant atmosphere. The collision between the wind from the white dwarf and the two shells from the red giant occurred within less than 2 years, causing the shock front to expand and the ionization parameter to decrease.
</summary>

The text discusses the importance of tidal interactions in close binary systems, such as star-star or star-planet configurations, and their role in various phenomena like synchronization, orbital circularization, tidal capture, disruption, and fall of an object onto a star. The paper specifically investigates the tidal interaction of two bodies, a star and a point source (which can be a star or a planet), while considering the evolution of the star over long timescales. The authors calculate the normal modes of stellar perturbations and the energy and angular momentum exchange in the star-planet system to determine the dynamical tides. They focus on three types of stars with different masses and investigate the tidal evolution by taking into account the stellar evolution.

The text discusses the use of fluorescence microscopy in nano-optics to overcome the diffraction limit in light microscopy, allowing for noninvasive imaging of the interior of cells and the detection of specific cellular constituents. However, the technique is limited by the optical transparency of the media surrounding the light emitters, and certain biological tissues or soft-matter systems can appear turbid due to intense scattering of photons. The paper proposes a new approach to obtain information about the relative distance between two identical incoherent point sources in a disordered environment, based on the analysis of the fluctuations of the emitted light.

Graphene research has attracted interest from various communities, including those looking to create atomic scale circuit devices and those searching for new topological phases. Both communities have sought to gap the massless Dirac spectrum, with the realization of a gate-induced band gap in Bernal stacked bi-layer graphene bringing the possibility of a graphene-based transistor closer to reality. However, the sub-gap conductance measured in this gapped bilayer is not as insulating as expected, introducing a new puzzle and obstacle.

The fundamental atmospheric and physical parameters of stars, such as effective temperature, surface gravity, metallicity, mass, and age, are crucial for chemo-dynamical studies of the Milky Way and other galaxies in the Local Group. Large spectroscopic surveys, like SEGUE, RAVE, Gaia-ESO, and HERMES, use these parameters to infer the characteristics of different populations of stars in the Milky Way. Stellar parameters determined by spectroscopic methods are of key importance, as metallicity can only be accurately measured through spectroscopy. High-resolution spectroscopy is used to correct low-resolution results. Atmospheric parameters can be estimated from a spectrum in a consistent and efficient way, avoiding the problem of reddening inherent in photometry. Spectroscopic parameters can then be used alone or in combination with photometric information to fit individual stars to theoretical isochrones or evolutionary tracks to determine the stellar mass, age, and distance of a star. A common method for deriving spectroscopic atmospheric parameters is to use the information from Fe and Fe absorption lines under the assumption of hydrostatic equilibrium and local thermodynamic equilibrium. However, both observational and theoretical evidence suggests that systematic biases are present within such analyses due to the breakdown of the assumption of LTE, particularly at low metallicity and/or surface gravity.

The kinetics of polymer loop formation has been studied for its importance in biology, with DNA loop formation being a crucial process for genetic expression, replication, and recombination. Recent research has shown that fluctuating forces in the cell interior, which can be an order of magnitude larger than expected, play a pivotal role in DNA looping. Single molecule experiments have provided detailed information on DNA loop formation, revealing the effects of tension and torsion on the process. However, there is no unifying theoretical framework to explain the variety of experimental results. Theoretical studies have been conducted to understand DNA bending on short length scales, as well as the effects of tension on loop formation. Experimental research on protein-mediated DNA loop formation has shown that a tension of 0.5 pN can increase the looping time by more than two orders of magnitude for loop sizes larger than 100 base pair distances. A model of DNA conformation as either a looped or unlooped state has been used to study the effects of static tension on protein-mediated DNA loop formation, but there is room for improvement in the evaluation of the free energy and the description of detailed kinetic processes.

The phase-field method is a popular tool for simulating microstructure formation during solidification due to its algorithmic simplicity. However, there are still open questions and challenges in developing robust phase-field modeling tools. The thin-interface limit of two-sided phase-field models cannot eliminate all effects linked to the finite interface thickness. Orientation-field models for polycrystalline solidification are not appropriate for the evolution of coherent crystalline matter. Including microscopic fluctuations in the phase-field equations is challenging, and the standard approach cannot be used to investigate the process of nucleation. The precision and performance of phase-field models have been enhanced, but controlling physical effects due to the diffuseness of the interface is necessary. The thin-interface limit is used to analyze the equations of the phase-field model, yielding effective boundary conditions that contain all effects of the finite interface thickness. This method was pioneered by Karma and Rappel and has made it possible to carry out quantitative simulations of free dendritic growth of a pure substance. However, generalizing this method to a model with arbitrary diffusivities is not trivial, and several new thin-interface effects appear, which cannot be eliminated simultaneously. A solution was found for the one-sided model with the introduction of the antitrapping current, making quantitative simulations of alloy solidification possible. Recently, several extensions of the antitrapping current have been put forward, but there is a second, independent thin-interface effect that cannot be removed by an antitrapping current, namely, the Kapitza resistance.

The text discusses the use of scalar diquark fields to construct tetraquark currents, and the application of this approach to the study of nonet scalar mesons using new QCD sum rules. The results are compatible with experimental data and theoretical estimations, and the diquark currents have the advantage of satisfying the criteria of QCD sum rules more easily compared to conventional quark currents.

The cell's mechanical behavior is often described as viscoelastic, and its rheological properties have been compared to minimalistic in vitro reconstituted constructs of the cytoskeleton. Various mathematical models, such as the glassy wormlike chain model, have been successful in describing the viscoelastic behavior of polymer solutions and living cells. However, recent investigations have highlighted the glassy, fragile, and inelastic characteristics of the mechanical response of living cells. Even for biopolymer networks in vitro, experiments operating in the nonlinear regime have had to use special protocols to minimize plastic flow and make contact with dedicated theoretical models. The present contribution aims to extend the theoretical modeling to include inelastic deformations, starting with reversible inelastic behavior where the deformation does not alter the microscopic ground state. The paper also discusses the relevance of structural heterogeneities in networks of semiflexible polymers for the mechanical properties.

Ionizable polymers in water can be classified as polyelectrolytes or polyampholytes, depending on the charge of their monomers. The sequence of charged monomers in polyampholytes significantly affects their behavior and interactions with other charged polymers. Charged polymers anchored on a surface can form a brush, which can be polyelectrolyte or polyampholyte depending on the charge of the monomers. The properties of polyelectrolyte brushes are determined by electrostatic interactions, while those of polyampholyte brushes are mainly determined by the chains' properties.

The source document discusses the use of permutations in the succinct encoding of various data types, and the efficient computation of permutations and their inverses. It also explores the relationship between sorting algorithms and encoding schemes for permutations, and the use of compression schemes for permutations in various applications. The document also describes several encodings of permutations that use a small number of bits while supporting various operations on the permutations.

The text discusses the topic of anisotropic quantum scattering in two spatial dimensions, particularly in the context of exotic and highly correlated quantum systems with dipolar gases. Recent experimental production of ultracold polar molecules in optical traps and the development of techniques for creating quasi-2d bose and fermi ultracold gases have stimulated interest in this area, as well as the long history of research in 2d quantum effects in condensed matter physics. The text also describes a method for quantitative analysis of 2d quantum scattering on a long-range strongly anisotropic scatterer, which permits the description of collisions of unpolarized dipoles.

1. The text discusses the behavior of lanthanide-based heavy fermion (HF) metals, which have distinct properties from conventional clean metals due to strong spin-flip scattering from essentially localized f-levels.
2. At low temperatures, HF metals exhibit a lattice-coherent Fermi liquid state with well-defined quasiparticles and coherently screened f-spins, transitioning to incoherent screening via independent Kondo scattering at higher temperatures.
3. Theoretical treatments of HF metals often rely on the Periodic Anderson Model (PAM) or its strong coupling limit, the Kondo lattice model.
4. Dynamical Mean Field Theory (DMFT) is a widely used approximation scheme for solving the PAM, mapping the lattice model onto an effective single-impurity model with a self-consistently determined host.
5. The text explores the extent to which the properties of real HF materials are captured within a DMFT approach to the PAM, requiring direct quantitative comparisons of theory to experiment.
6. Various methods have been employed to solve the PAM, including Numerical Renormalization Group (NRG), Quantum Monte Carlo (QMC), Exact Diagonalization, and several theoretical approaches.
7. The Local Moment Approach (LMA) is used in the study, providing a many-body description of dynamical and transport properties of paramagnetic HF metals.
8. The LMA is a non-perturbative technique that introduces the notion of local moments, leading to a two-self-energy description that captures correlated spin-flip dynamics.
9. The LMA has been successful in describing the dynamics and static magnetic properties of the single-impurity Anderson model and has been extended to the Anderson lattice model.
10. The paper focuses on results obtained using the LMA, with minimal technical details, and aims to provide a many-body description of dynamical and transport properties of paramagnetic HF metals, making direct quantitative comparisons with experiment.

A peculiar dynamical phenomenon known as chimera states, which involves the coexistence of coherent and incoherent oscillations in populations of identical phase oscillators, has been observed in various models and experimental setups. In this paper, the authors identify and classify different types of single and multi-chimera states in networks of non-locally coupled neurons represented by Hindmarsh-Rose oscillators, both in 2D and 3D versions, and investigate their emergence and properties in relation to network parameters and coupling schemes.

Time-domain simulation of power system dynamic analysis is important but can be expensive due to the large number of differential and algebraic equations (DAEs) representing different components and time scales. Intense efforts have been made to accelerate the simulation of long-term stability models, including using larger time step sizes and implementing the quasi-steady-state (QSS) model. However, the QSS model suffers from numerical difficulties and may not provide consistent approximations. This paper aims to improve the QSS model by applying pseudo-transient continuation (PTC) method, a theoretically-based numerical method in power system long-term stability analysis. PTC can accelerate simulation speed and overcome possible numerical difficulties in both the long-term stability model and the QSS model. The paper is organized into four sections, including a review of PTC in DAE systems, implementation of PTC in power system models, numerical examples, and conclusions.

Kauffman networks are disordered dynamical systems used as a model for genetic regulatory systems, which underwent study in the framework of mean field theory and statistical mechanics. This paper introduces the notion of "relevant elements" in these networks and studies their probability distribution, which will be used to describe the phase transition in random Boolean networks in terms of a percolation transition in the set of relevant elements. The authors also propose a new approximation scheme for studying the statistical properties of the attractors in the frozen phase and on the critical line.

The effects of weak gravitational lensing by the large-scale structure have been detected in various samples of high-redshift QSOs, intermediate-redshift galaxies, and BATSE GRBs. Weak lensing can manifest itself as angular (anti-)correlations between these sources and foreground inhomogeneously distributed mass, or as a coherent shear effect in the case of galaxies. A more direct way of detecting weak lensing uses fluxes of standard candles, with the effect of lensing causing brighter sources to lie behind regions of mass density excess and fainter sources to have mass deficits in their foregrounds. Supernovae Type Ia (SNe Ia) are the best example of cosmological standard candles, and have been extensively observed to determine the global geometry of the universe. Nuisance effects like evolution, variations in individual SNe, and gray dust extinction have been studied and accounted for. Weak lensing, another nuisance effect, has been addressed theoretically and found to be unimportant given current uncertainties. The largest homogeneous compilation of SNe Ia contains 74 SNe at various redshifts, and the authors use four different light curve fitting methods to estimate distances to the SNe. The final quoted distance is the median of the estimates of the four individual methods, and the uncertainty is the median of the error of the contributing methods. The analysis presented in the paper yields values of the global cosmological parameters, which are used in the analysis of the present paper. As tracers of foreground mass density, APM galaxies are used, which provide near full coverage of the sky in the northern and southern hemispheres. In the analysis, only the central regions of APM plates are used, resulting in small portions of the sky not being covered. Of the 74 SNe Ia in the compilation, only 55 lie on the usable parts of APM plates. The median redshift of the 55 SNe Ia is 0.126. The main goal of the work is to determine if the observed fluxes of cosmologically distant SNe Ia have suffered significantly from lensing-induced (de-)amplifications.

White dwarf (WD) stars, which represent the end points of stellar evolution for most low-mass stars, become pulsating variable stars when they reach a certain temperature and develop a hydrogen partial ionization zone. It is now believed that all DA WDs will pass through the ZZ Ceti instability strip and pulsate at some point in their evolution, although some may pulsate at low amplitudes that are difficult to detect.

The text discusses the phenomenon of turbulence in quantum fluids, where many quantized vortices with quantized circulation are nucleated, forming tangles. This is different from classical turbulence, where the circulation of the velocity field is not quantized. The text also discusses the studies of turbulence in multi-component Bose-Einstein condensates (BECs), where not only a velocity field but also a (quasi) spin field exists, leading to various topological excitations. The text further focuses on the study of turbulence in a spin-1 ferromagnetic spinor BEC, where the spin field is disturbed, leading to spin turbulence (ST). The paper aims to treat the problem of coupled turbulence with two fields in ST, leading to a new phenomenon called spin-superflow turbulence (SST).

The recent discovery of a resonance at 125 GeV at the Large Hadron Collider is a major step towards understanding the origin of mass for fundamental particles, and may also affect the field of gravitation in models where the Higgs field has nonminimal coupling to the general relativity sector. Bounds on the gravitational interaction of Higgs bosons and the crosstalk between the Higgs particle and gravity have been discussed in the context of strong-gravity astrophysical objects such as active galactic nuclei and primordial black holes.

The discovery of an overdensity of stars in the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) has been interpreted as an intervening population of stars that may represent a dwarf galaxy or tidal debris. This overdensity, labeled the VRC, has been studied extensively, but its origin remains debated. Some argue that it is a massive foreground population, while others suggest it is the result of stellar evolution within the LMC. The debate has implications for the interpretation of galactic microlensing studies, as the VRC could be responsible for a significant fraction of the microlensing signal.

Topological insulators (TIs) are a class of materials with non-trivial topological invariants and robust surface metallic states, which have been intensively studied due to their potential applications. These TIs are typically realized in systems with strong spin-orbit interaction and time-reversal symmetry. However, all known TIs contain heavy or rare metal elements, which poses constraints on the search for topological materials. A proposed solution is to generate effective spin-orbit couplings from ubiquitous Coulomb repulsions among electrons. An extended Hubbard model on the honeycomb lattice has been proposed to generate an effective spin-orbit interaction from a spontaneous symmetry breaking at the Hartree-Fock mean-field level, leading to a topologically non-trivial phase called a topological Mott insulator (TMI). However, realizing this proposed topological phase in real materials has not been achieved, and the stability of TMIs against competing orders and quantum fluctuations is not clear. Reliable examination of stable topological mott orders in the extended Hubbard model is hampered by competing symmetry breakings such as charge density waves (CDWs). Couplings driving the topological Mott transitions are also relevant to formations of a CDW, which has not been satisfactorily discussed in previous studies. The emergence of the TMI in the honeycomb lattice requires the Coulomb repulsion between the next nearest neighbor sites, and the long-period CDW instability must be considered on equal footing, which is not captured in the small-unit-cell mean-field ansatz employed in previous studies. Examining charge fluctuations with finite momentum over entire Brillouin zones is an alternative way to clarify the competitions among TMIs and CDWs, as studied by employing functional renormalization group methods. However, first-order thermal or quantum phase transitions not characterized by diverging order-parameter fluctuations are hardly captured by such theoretical methods. The most plausible symmetry-breaking competing with TMIs indeed occurs as a first-order quantum phase transition, and quantum many-body fluctuations beyond the mean-field approximation severely affect the stability of the TMI. The stability of the TMI and estimation of the critical value of interaction on the honeycomb lattice has mainly been considered by mean-field calculations, which can not treat the correlation effect satisfactorily.
