The study focuses on the Netherlands and investigates the relationship between personal and neighborhood environmental characteristics and active transport among inhabitants of Dutch deprived neighborhoods. The findings suggest that more favorable neighborhood characteristics are associated with higher levels of activity, and that there are differences in the way certain subgroups respond to environmental features. The study highlights the importance of considering neighborhood characteristics in efforts to promote physical activity, particularly in low-SES populations.

Delirium is a common and severe complication in elderly patients, associated with increased morbidity, mortality, prolonged hospital stay, and higher risk of post-discharge institutionalization and dementia. Identifying accurate biomarkers for delirium could help improve recognition and care. Oxidative stress and disturbances in serotonergic and dopaminergic neurotransmission may be involved in delirium's pathophysiology. A study investigating biochemical parameters in patients with and without delirium found that patients with delirium had significantly lower mean levels of arginine and higher mean phe/tyr ratios, suggesting deficiency in the essential cofactor BH4 for the production of serotonin, dopamine, and nitric oxide (NO). Additionally, patients with delirium had significantly lower mean trp/lnaas ratios, which might indicate reduced serotonin production in the central nervous system. These findings suggest that disturbed serotonergic neurotransmission and increased oxidative stress status may play a role in delirium's pathogenesis. However, dopaminergic neurotransmission does not seem to be impaired during delirium. Further research is needed to confirm these results and explore potential differences in the pathophysiology of delirium in patients with and without cognitive disorders.

The Behavioral Health Home (BHH) is a new healthcare delivery model aimed at improving preventative care for individuals with Serious Mental Illness (SMI), who have a higher rate of chronic conditions like diabetes. The BHH in this case study is embedded in the Division of Community Psychiatry at the University of Maryland School of Medicine and provides population-based care to identify and manage abnormal Hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) levels in patients with SMI. Preliminary results show that the BHH was able to identify gaps in care, such as missed laboratory monitoring and undiagnosed diabetes, in 54 out of 120 patients. Of the 33 patients identified with type 2 diabetes, 4 were newly diagnosed and 7 showed improvements in HbA1c levels. The use of BHH services has shown potential in delivering patient-centered primary care within the mental health setting and promoting proactive preventative care for individuals with SMI. However, more empirical data and research are needed to fully understand the impact of BHH services on this population.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic disease that can lead to decreased bone strength and increased risk of fractures due to impaired bone quality and density. This is caused by an imbalance in bone remodeling, which is affected by MS, reduced mobility, long-term glucocorticoid (GCS) treatment, and vitamin D deficiency. GCS treatment can further increase the risk of osteoporosis and fractures. Exercise, adequate nutrition, and maintaining a healthy lifestyle can help prevent skeletal fragility. Clinical evaluation of patients with MS should include assessment of risk factors for osteoporosis and fractures, such as level of disability, GCS treatment, and vitamin D deficiency. BMD testing should be conducted at the lumbar spine and hip, and follow-up scans should be done to monitor the course of the disease and response to therapy. Pharmacologic therapy should be considered in patients at high risk for osteoporosis, and calcium and vitamin D supplementation should be provided as an adjunct treatment.

The source discusses the relationship between lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) and erectile dysfunction (ED) in elderly men, and the potential benefits of treating LUTS to improve ED. A study is described where male patients with LUTS/benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and ED were divided into two groups, one receiving an alpha-blocker and the other receiving both an alpha-blocker and an antimuscarinic drug. The results showed that both groups had improved LUTS after treatment, but there was no significant difference in ED improvement between the two groups. The study suggests that treating LUTS may not significantly improve ED in patients with LUTS/BPH.

Human papillomavirus (HPV) is a DNA virus that infects the mucosal areas of the human upper digestive tract and anogenital region through sexual contact, leading to an increased risk of cancer. There are high-risk and low-risk HPV genotypes, with high-risk genotypes causing cervical cancer and other mucosal anogenital and head and neck cancers. Low-risk genotypes can cause benign or low-grade cervical tissue changes and genital warts. HPV infection is one of the most common sexually transmitted infections in sexually active adolescents and young women. The seroprevalence of HPV in Nigeria is high, and women aged 15-23 years have the highest prevalence. High-risk HPV genital infections in young females are transient and have little long-term significance, but when the infection persists, there is a high risk of developing a precancerous lesion of the cervix. Detection of anti-HPV has been shown to reflect the overall HPV infection rate in a population more effectively than detection of HPV DNA. In this study, HPV igg antibodies were detected in serum samples from 42.9% of women, indicating that the women had been infected and that the virus is circulating with a high prevalence in Kaduna state. The study recommends improving knowledge at the population level by education on the mode of transmission of the virus and the risks associated with the virus as a cause of cervical cancer. In addition, cervical cancer screening programs need to be put in place in Nigeria, given that cervical cancer has been shown to disproportionately affect African American women, who are nearly twice more likely than European American women to die of the disease.

Optic neuritis is an acute optic neuropathy that frequently occurs in young women as the first clinical presentation of multiple sclerosis (MS). The study, conducted at the Eye Clinic and Neurological Clinic of Sarajevo University Clinical Centre from March 2009 to 2011, analyzed patients with unilateral optic neuritis and verified MS diagnosis. The results showed that optic neuritis was most common in patients aged 18 to 30 years and more frequent in female patients. The first clinical manifestation of MS in the sample was statistically significant, confirming optic neuritis as one of the first clinical manifestations of MS. Ophthalmological parameters, including visual acuity, visual field, and thickness of the peripapillary rim nerve fibers, were analyzed in the study. A month after pulse corticosteroid therapy, all patients with optic neuritis had a significant improvement in visual acuity. The study also found that 50% of the patients with optic neuritis developed MS over a 15-year period, and all patients had oct-verified nerve fiber atrophy after optic neuritis. The analysis of the computerized visual field confirmed centrocecal disturbances as the most common, and optic coherent tomography registered the thinning of the nerve fibers of the neuroretinal rim in all subjects.

The group is discussing the budget balancing of a product, which involves using standard off-the-shelf components, an advanced chip, and an LCD display. They are considering using a plastic case and rubber grip for ergonomics, but are concerned about the cost. They plan to present a prototype, which has been modified due to budget constraints, for evaluation.

In the last meeting, the team discussed the minutes from the previous meeting and presented a prototype for a remote control. The prototype is designed to be ergonomic, with a banana shape and a yellow color, and simple to use with a scroll wheel and a small LCD screen. The team also evaluated the prototype based on user complaints and feedback, and discussed the budget and costs. They decided to remove the LCD screen to reduce the cost and make the design even simpler. The team was satisfied with the project process and thought they had good teamwork, creativity, and means for the project.

<summary> Human metapneumovirus (HMPV) is a negative single-stranded RNA virus of the family Paramyxoviridae, closely related to avian metapneumovirus (AMPV) subgroup C. It is a major cause of respiratory tract infections (RTI) in infants, the elderly, and immunocompromised individuals. Genome sequencing and comparative analysis can provide insights into the pathogenicity, evolution history, and cell-host interaction of HMPV. The HMPV genome is approximately 13 kb in length, with a gene composition of n-p-m-f-m2-1/m2-2-sh-g-l. Its genomic organization is similar to human respiratory syncytial virus (HRSV), lacking two nonstructural genes, ns1 and ns2. HMPV has two main genetic lineages, subtype A and B, which further divide into subgroups a1/a2 and b1/b2. The a2 sublineage exhibits the greatest diversity among all sublineages. Synonymous codon usage bias in HMPV can offer insights into its evolution profile, gene expression, and virus-host interaction. A study of 17 complete HMPV genomes revealed that preferred codons in HMPV are ended with a/u, suggesting a strong synonymous codon usage bias influenced by the nucleotide composition in its genomes. The g+c content of the HMPV genome is 36.91%, and over 68.57% of codons are ended with a/u. Natural selection and mutation pressure are key factors affecting codon usage patterns in organisms, and in HMPV, mutation pressure rather than natural selection is the most important determinant of codon usage. Codon usage bias in HMPV shows distinct differences among different phylogenetic types, suggesting its role in HMPV's evolution history. HMPV shows a complementary trend with human cells in codon usage, which may contribute to its persistent infection in the human environment and understanding cell-host interaction and viral evolution.
</summary>

Note: The summary is concise and covers the main points of the source document. However, due to the complexity and density of information provided, some details had to be omitted

Hefin David AM asked about the effectiveness and balance of the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015 in regulating universities and private providers, to which Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, discussed the government's intention to supercede the Act with the new Post-compulsory Education and Training Bill, aiming to strengthen or add to the existing objectives while ensuring legislation is fit for the current circumstances and futureproof. The discussion also covered the role of HEFCW, the potential for national outcomes in legislation, and the regulation of part-time and postgraduate fees.

In a meeting, the project manager and user interface specialist introduce the prototype of a remote control. The prototype is designed based on trends such as a fancy look-and-feel, limited buttons, simplicity, and a spongy feel. The team also considered other devices like the iPod and a kid's remote for inspiration. The remote is designed in the shape of a banana, with a yellow color and a scroll wheel for controlling. The team also discusses the budget and evaluates the prototype based on user complaints and criteria such as simplicity for new users and technological innovation. They determine that the remote is not completely successful in solving the problem of being easily lost, and they consider adding features such as speech recognition or a proximity alarm to improve this. The team ultimately decides that the remote is technologically innovative and fashionable, and they calculate an average score of 2.42 out of 7 for the criteria they evaluated.

The team discussed the product evaluation of a remote control's feature aimed at addressing customers' concerns. The prototype presentation was based on a banana design with a yellow color and ergonomic grips. The controlling would be done with a scroll wheel and the simplest functions would be similar to an iPod. The team also considered adding speech recognition and an infrared beam for on and off function. They also discussed the components, materials, and energy sources for the prototype. The team aimed to incorporate fashion trends such as a fancy look-and-feel, fruit and vegetable patterns, and a spongy feel. They also wanted limited buttons and simplicity. The team had looked into other devices such as the iPod and a kid's remote for inspiration. They had also considered a two-part remote and speech recognition but decided not to go with it. The team had made a decision on the components, materials, and energy sources for the prototype. The budget and any changes needed after the evaluation were also discussed.

The project manager summarizes the previous meeting's decisions, mentioning the group's agreement on using a new black design with an LCD display and standard components. Two designers present a prototype with an ergonomic design, including an adjustable joystick position for handedness. The group discusses the use of a plastic casing with a rubber grip for improved ergonomics and cost reduction. <summary> Malaria, caused by Plasmodium parasites, is a major health issue in many tropical regions, with Plasmodium falciparum being the most prevalent species. The primary transmission occurs through the bite of infected Anopheles mosquitoes, such as Anopheles darlingi in Brazil. The Brazilian Ministry of Health provides free antimalarial medicines, including chloroquine and primaquine, to treat malaria. Chloroquine is used to treat Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale in Brazil, while primaquine is the only antimalarial drug effective against all Plasmodium species gametocytes and hypnozoites. However, primaquine can cause hemolytic anemia, especially in people with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. A study in the municipality of Mâncio Lima, Acre, Brazil, evaluated the frequency of symptoms in vivax malaria before and after treatment with chloroquine and primaquine. The study found that chloroquine and primaquine can lead to the onset of symptoms or intensify some malaria symptoms. Gastrointestinal symptoms, such as nausea, diarrhea, and abdominal pain, were more common after treatment initiation. Additionally, chloroquine can cause neurological and cardiovascular symptoms, while primaquine can cause hemolytic anemia, which can be severe in people with G6PD deficiency. The prevalence of G6PD deficiency varies globally, and in Brazil, primaquine is administered to all nonpregnant patients over six months of age without G6PD deficiency screening. It is essential to monitor patients for possible adverse effects and consider G6PD deficiency status before administering primaquine. </summary>

Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Huw Morris, director of the skills, higher education and lifelong learning group in Welsh Government, discussed the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015 during a post-legislative scrutiny session. Williams stated that the Act will be superceded by the new PCETR Bill and that there are experiences from the implementation of the Act that they want to reflect on as they take forward the new Bill. She mentioned that the four strategic aims of the Act are still relevant but they need legislation that is fit for the current circumstances and futureproofs the sector. When asked if the legislation itself hasn't been strong enough, Williams stated that she sees the remit letter as a very important mechanism for ensuring that national priorities are clearly articulated and change happens. She also mentioned that the 2015 Act contains numerous provisions that protect universities' privileges and autonomy and that they will look to carry those protections into the forthcoming Bill.

1. Specific miRNAs are expressed in a cell-type specific manner, during developmental stages and in disease states including cancer.
2. In cancer, miRNAs can act as oncogenes or tumor suppressors, with some being overexpressed and others lost, often localizing to fragile sites.
3. Differences in miRNA expression profiles have been documented in normal compared to cancerous tissue of the endometrium, breast, and ovary.
4. miRNAs can affect the expression of a large number of proteins, including those involved in pathways relevant to cancer, such as apoptosis, migration, and metastasis.
5. Epithelial to mesenchymal transition (EMT) is a normal process during development, but is also used by cancer cells to become more motile and metastatic.
6. EMT involves reprogramming of the cells by transcription factors such as Zeb1, Zeb2, Twist, Snail, and Slug, leading to loss of E-cadherin expression, loss of polarity, acquisition of mesenchymal markers, and increased motility.
7. The miR-200 family, which contains five members, has been implicated in the process of EMT. Members of this family can repress both Zeb1 and Zeb2, leading to upregulation of E-cadherin.
8. A double negative feedback loop between miR-200 family members and Zeb1 allows for plasticity between the epithelial and mesenchymal states.
9. The mutual repression between Zeb1 and mir-200c is functional in some, but not all cells, and the decrease in migration and invasion observed when mir-200c is reintroduced to cancer cells is independent of restoration of E-cadherin.
10. Repression of tubb3 by mir-200c restores sensitivity to paclitaxel, indicating that loss of mir-200c is a marker for chemoresistance and aggressiveness in breast, ovarian, and endometrial cancers.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a meeting to conduct post-legislative scrutiny on the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015. Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Huw Morris, Director of the Skills, Higher Education and Lifelong Learning Group in Welsh Government, attended the meeting. The Minister stated that the 2015 Act will be superceded by the new Post-Compulsory Education and Training Bill, and they will consider what can be learned from the implementation of the 2015 Act. The Minister also mentioned that they will look to strengthen or do more to achieve the four strategic aims of the 2015 Act, which are around regulation of institutions in Wales, safeguarding the contribution made to public good, maintaining a focus on fair access, and preserving and protecting the principle of institutional autonomy.

The transobturator approach to treat female stress urinary incontinence by placing a midurethral sling (MUS) was first described by Delorme as an alternative to the retropubic approach to reduce complications. Two variations of the transobturator approach are the outside-in and inside-out methods. A meta-analysis found similar cure rates for the three most common surgical approaches for stress urinary incontinence, including the retropubic, outside-in transobturator, and inside-out transobturator MUS procedures. Anatomical studies have confirmed the safety of both obturator approaches in relation to neurovascular structures, but traditional anatomical dissections do not allow for the study of the MUS's configuration in relation to the urethra. A cadaveric study was conducted to compare the specific relationship between the tape and the urethra in both the inside-out and outside-in approach using CT scan image analysis. The study found that the out-in MUS had a larger full inner angle (144 degrees) compared to the in-out MUS (122 degrees) in a strict antero-posterior view. The use of tantalum wires threaded through the polypropylene-/prolene-tape in combination with three-dimensional CT-scanning provided a unique method to visualize midurethral tapes throughout the entirety of their trajectory. This technique can be applied to different types of non radio-opaque implants, allowing for a better spatial understanding of the anatomical position within the pelvis. The study also found that both obturator MUS approaches were demonstrated to be u-shaped bands that head backwards or dorsally, and the tape is not positioned caudally but lies as a band behind the urethra, suggestive of its passive (non-obstructive) role in achieving continence. The clinical implications from this cadaveric imaging study are that surgeons must pay more attention to the second half of the helical pass, whichever way they chose to go. The advent of three-dimensional ultrasonography will allow for similar measurements of the different tapes trajectories in vivo in a dynamic setting, possibly allowing correlation of these findings to nuances in clinical outcomes. In a meeting, the team discussed the functional requirements of a remote control. Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Huw Morris, director of the skills, higher education and lifelong learning group in Welsh Government, discussed the post-legislative scrutiny of the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015. The Minister stated that the Act will be superceded by the new PCETR Bill, and the government plans to reflect on what has worked and what hasn't in the implementation of the Act. Sian Gwenllian AM asked if the Act has fulfilled all government objectives, to which the Minister responded that while the four strategic aims of the Act are still relevant, the higher education and research Bill across the border in England and the implementation of new student support measures in Wales necessitate different proposals. The Minister also mentioned that the remit letter is an important mechanism for ensuring national priorities are clearly articulated and acted upon. In response to a question about institutional autonomy, the Minister stated that the 2015 Act contains provisions that protect universities' privileges and autonomy, and these protections will be carried into the forthcoming Bill. The Minister also mentioned that the government is considering how to regulate the part of the sector that provides higher education in Wales but is not currently regulated by the Act. The Minister stated that the charitable status of institutions will likely continue in the new legislation. The Minister also mentioned that the government is not currently planning to regulate postgraduate and part-time fees in the new legislation. The Minister discussed the benefits of having national targets to get institutions to address national priorities, and stated that the government is looking to move to a system of outcome agreements where the outputs will reflect national priorities. The Minister also mentioned that the government is considering how to regulate alternative private providers under the new legislation.

The group discussed the format for storing and accessing annotated speech data. They considered using an existing format called P-file, which is a binary representation of features and has tools already available for it. They also discussed the possibility of using the ATLAS framework developed by NIST, which provides a more general and flexible structure for storing annotated data. The group decided to further explore the ATLAS framework and its suitability for their needs. They also discussed the importance of having a flexible and extensible format to accommodate different types of annotations and future extensions. The group agreed to look into the ATLAS framework and report back on their findings. Additionally, they discussed the possibility of using a relational database to store the annotated data, which would allow for more efficient querying and analysis. However, it was decided that a flat file format might be sufficient for their current needs and could be easily extended to a database format in the future if needed.

The Welsh Government is working on simplifying the early childhood education and care system, which has grown complex over time. They are considering ways to join up services provided by health boards and local authorities. A pilot project in eight local authorities is looking at how to create a more joined-up and responsive system. The focus is on both children and parents, with the aim of providing high-quality early childhood education and care that supports children's development and helps parents work. The Welsh Government is also considering the possibility of extending the childcare offer to parents who are in education and training.

Julie Morgan, Deputy Minister for Health and Social Services, discussed the Welsh Government's approach to early childhood education and care. The focus is on supporting both children and parents, with an aim to simplify the complex system of programs and funding. A pilot program in eight local authorities is testing ways to join up the early years system, and an announcement about the direction of these efforts is expected soon. The Welsh Government's Childcare Offer for Wales, which supports working parents, has seen high take-up rates in some areas but not others, leading to concerns about consistency and access. The Minister also discussed Flying Start, a program targeting areas with high levels of income-dependent households, and the role of health visitors in supporting parents.

The Deputy Minister mentioned challenges in simplifying the complex early childhood education and care system and expressed hope for an announcement before Christmas.

Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Huw Morris, director of the skills, higher education and lifelong learning group in Welsh Government, attended a meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee to discuss post-legislative scrutiny of the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015. Williams stated that the government plans to supercede the 2015 Act with the new Post-compulsory Education and Training Bill, and will consider experiences and evidence from the implementation of the 2015 Act as they move forward. She noted that the four strategic aims of the 2015 Act - regulation of institutions, safeguarding the contribution made to public good, maintaining a focus on fair access, and preserving institutional autonomy - are still important, but may need to be strengthened or approached differently in the new legislation. Sian Gwenllian AM asked whether the legislation itself has not been strong enough, and whether that is why certain objectives have been driven through the annual remit letter. Williams responded that she sees the remit letter as a valuable mechanism for ensuring national priorities are clearly articulated and acted upon. Gwenllian also asked whether the current legislation has framed around institutional autonomy in a way that makes it difficult for institutions to fulfill national outcomes, and whether this will be addressed in the new Bill. Williams stated that while the 2015 Act contains provisions protecting universities' privileges and autonomy, the new Bill will aim to balance appropriate regulation and accountability with institutional autonomy. She also noted the importance of the working relationship between the Welsh Government and the sector in achieving national priorities. Gwenllian asked about private providers and whether the requirement for a regulated institution to be a charity makes it difficult to regulate alternative private providers. Williams stated that the scale of private providers in Wales is small, and that there is a process in place to manage this. She also noted that the new legislation will consider how this part of the sector will be regulated. Finally, Gwenllian asked about the regulation of part-time and postgraduate fees, and Williams stated that there is not currently an urgent reason to designate these courses as qualifying courses for the purposes of a fee limit, but that this will be kept under review.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee discussed differences in care provision in different parts of Wales with Julie Morgan AM, Deputy Minister for Health and Social Services; Jo-anne Daniels, director of communities and tackling poverty at Welsh Government; and Nicola Edwards, deputy director of the childcare, play and early years division in Welsh Government. The Deputy Minister stated that the Welsh Government's approach is to support both children and parents, with a high-quality early childhood education and care system. Hefin David AM asked about the focus of the Welsh Government's plans, to which the Deputy Minister replied that they want to give parents the opportunity to work without childcare being a barrier, while ensuring that children have the best experience in the early years. The Deputy Minister mentioned that the Welsh Government is working on a review of the Childcare Offer for Wales to extend it to parents who are in education and training, and hopes to make an announcement soon. Janet Finch-Saunders AM asked about the big differences in the amount of early childhood education and care provision available in different parts of Wales, to which the Deputy Minister replied that there are historical reasons for the variation and that the Welsh Government is looking at ways of simplifying the system. The Deputy Minister also mentioned a pilot in Flintshire that is testing the impact of consistent funding rates for education and childcare, and will have an independent evaluation in November 2019.

In this meeting, the team discussed the conceptual design for a remote control. The industrial designer presented their review of available components, including energy sources such as solar, hand dynamo, and kinetic techniques, and potential case materials like wood, rubber, titanium, and latex. The interface can have simple buttons or more complex scrolls, but this requires a more complicated chip. The team considered using a basic battery or kinetic energy collection as the energy source, and titanium as the case material. They also discussed using rubber buttons for the interface to achieve desired functionalities with a regular chip, which is cheaper. The remote control will have a single curved shape for a comfortable grip. The battery can be recharged using kinetic energy collected by moving the arm. The team will check with their R&D department to see if the kinetic metal is sufficient to provide enough energy. The user interface will use a graphical representation of buttons as figures, diagrams, or symbols, making it easy to understand the function of each button. The team also discussed using voice recognition technology, which is ready to be used, and a spinning wheel with an LCD display as alternative navigation tools. They also discussed the possibility of using a scroll button and customizable features for different users, such as children, handicapped people, and old people. The team decided to focus on the fancy look and speech recognition if the technology is available, but they will consider the cost of implementing these features. They also discussed the possibility of a function that reminds the user to charge the remote control when the TV is switched off. The team will define the set of vocabularies for the speech recognizer and check with the R&D department the capability of the recognizer. They also discussed the possibility of using a snapshot of every channel on the TV screen to make it easier for the user to navigate through the channels. The team will consider the practical problems discussed in the meeting, such as distinguishing between different users' voices and the potential failure of voice commands in noisy environments, in the design. The meeting was then closed, and the team agreed to discuss these issues further in the next meeting.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee of the National Assembly for Wales held an evidence session to discuss the impact of Brexit on higher and further education in Wales. Kirsty Williams, Cabinet Secretary for Education, and Eluned Morgan AM, Minister for Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning, attended the session. They were joined by Huw Morris, group director at SHELL, and Marie Knox, deputy director overseeing European transition. The committee discussed the preparedness of higher education institutions for Brexit, the potential impact of a 'no deal' scenario, and the work being done to mitigate risks. The committee also discussed the impact of Brexit on further education, including the potential loss of European funding and the importance of maintaining learning opportunities. The committee was informed that there are no formal risk assessments available for scrutiny, but that officers have been visiting individual institutions to ensure they have their own plans in place. The committee also discussed the European transition team, which meets fortnightly to coordinate Brexit preparations within the Welsh Government.

They agreed on the requirements and target market, which are using default materials and targeting sixty to eighty year old customers. The team also discussed the possibility of using kinetic energy as an alternative to batteries for the remote control, but decided against it due to potential issues with user experience and cost. They also discussed the possibility of changing case covers for the remote control, and agreed that it was a good option for adding value to the product.

The team discussed the production finance for their project and created separate folders for different documents. They discussed the prototype presentation, which includes a remote control with a total interface, number buttons, a page and sound button, a mute button, a battery indicator, and an on/off button. The team also evaluated the design of the remote control using a questionnaire with a seven-point scale. They discussed the features of the remote control, such as the LCD screen, microphone, and scroll button, and how they meet the requirements of the users. The team also discussed the finance aspect of the project and whether they can afford the designed remote control.

The group had a functional design meeting to discuss the new remote control project. The agenda included going over the functional design objectives, presentations on marketing, effects, and technical functions, and a discussion on remote control functions. The marketing report focused on user requirements, such as the desire for a remote that is not ugly and the willingness to pay more for a fancier looking one. Younger people were more inclined to want voice recognition, while older people were not. The group also discussed the problem of people losing their remotes and the desire to match operating behavior with remote functions. The meeting concluded with each member completing a questionnaire and summary, and discussing individual actions for their personal coaches.

A team is discussing the redesign of a conceptual remote control with a limited budget. They consider various features such as buttons, LCD screen, chip-on-print, sensor, kinetic energy, and color of the buttons. They also discuss the possibility of using an integrated scroll-wheel push-button and dropping certain features to save costs. Ultimately, they decide on a design with a plastic case, special color for the buttons, and one integrated scroll-wheel push-button. They also keep the LCD screen and drop the speech recognition feature.

The project manager is starting a meeting to discuss the functional design phase of a new remote control project. The marketing team has conducted research and found that users want a remote control with fewer buttons, but the important buttons should be larger and more durable. The industrial designer is considering the technical aspects of the remote control, including the use of a circuit board and the potential for a universal remote control. The team also discusses the possibility of adding a small LCD screen to the remote control for channel previews and other information.

The team discussed the product cost and evaluated the prototype of a handheld, single-handed remote control with a circular design for the numbers and a stress ball-like feel. They also discussed the use of interchangeable casing and different color combinations based on various fruits. The team considered the use of kinetic energy, a regular chip, plastic, rubber, push button interface, and a special color and form for the buttons. They found that they were just barely under budget. The team also discussed leadership, teamwork, and the project means, finding that they worked well together and had satisfactory means.

In a meeting, the project manager, marketing, user interface, and industrial designer discuss the design of a new remote control. Marketing suggests incorporating voice recognition software, but the project manager has concerns about power requirements, cost, and feasibility. They consider a joystick and LCD for additional functionality, and discuss the target audience and user interface design. The industrial designer presents the internal layout of the remote, including the energy source, user interface, and chip. The project manager raises concerns about the cost and ability to incorporate voice activation, and suggests a joystick and LCD for additional functionality. They discuss the possibility of targeting TV manufacturers rather than the public. The marketing expert mentions the need to sell a large number of units to cover the cost of remotes that are not sold. The project manager suggests incorporating a feature to locate the remote if lost, such as a beeping noise or flashing light. They discuss the feasibility of a small transmitter and LCD screen. The marketing expert will provide information on the frequency of remote control usage and the software side of the interface. The industrial designer will look into the feasibility of the speaker, LCD, and transmitter. They consider building the transmitter into the television. The project manager mentions the need to incorporate the company slogan into the design.

The project team, including a project manager, industrial designer, user interface designer, and marketing representative, discussed and evaluated a prototype for a new remote control design, which is mango-shaped, made of rubber for ergonomics and anti-RSI purposes, and has a circular design for the numbers. They also discussed the product's evaluation criteria, finances, and teamwork, and determined that the prototype matches their budget and requirements, with a few areas for improvement.

The team discussed the prototype presentation of a product, which is designed to be palm-held and have all buttons accessible from the thumb. The design is based on a mango shape with the company logo and LED on it. The team also talked about the use of a plus button for numbers larger than ten, which can be used to directly access channels like sixty-five. They also discussed the use of interchangeable casing for the product and considered a fruit and vegetable theme for the color combinations. The team also evaluated the prototype based on their original requirements and goals, and found that it meets most of them. They also discussed leadership, teamwork, and the resources provided for the project. The team was generally positive about the product and its design, and they plan to celebrate by watching TV using the new remote.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a meeting to discuss the impact of Brexit on higher and further education. Kirsty Williams, Cabinet Secretary for Education, and Eluned Morgan AM, Minister for Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning, were in attendance. They were joined by Huw Morris, group director at SHELL, and Marie Knox, deputy director overseeing European transition. The committee discussed the preparedness of higher education institutions for Brexit, with Suzy Davies AM asking about sector analyses and risk assessments. Kirsty Williams mentioned that each institution has its own exposure and potential impact, and that ongoing work is being done to refine approaches as the situation in London and Europe becomes clearer. Huw Morris added that officials have been visiting individual institutions to discuss their preparedness for a 'no deal' scenario. Suzy Davies also asked about the Cardiff University research on the impact of Brexit on the Welsh economy, and Huw Morris clarified that the research is specific to the economy brief and that the government has been doing its own research on the impact on HE, FE, and apprenticeship providers. Eluned Morgan discussed the impact on further education, stating that the number of EU students and staff in FE colleges is significantly lower than in HE institutions. She also mentioned that the real problems for FE may be in relation to ESF funding and apprenticeships, and that the link between apprenticeships and the local work community is crucial. The committee also discussed the European transition team, which meets fortnightly to build resilience within the Welsh Government for Brexit. Marie Knox, who attends the meetings in relation to HE and FE, explained that the team provides the governance structure for the Welsh Government and leads discussions with the Department for Exiting the European Union, No. 10, and the Joint Ministerial Committee.

The project manager is starting a meeting about the functional design phase of a product. The marketing director has had trouble with his computer, but he presents the findings of user research. Most users find remote controls ugly and want to spend money on a better system. The method used for research involved testing with a hundred people, both women and men. The findings reveal that 75% of users find most remote controls ugly, and 50% say they only use the power, channel selection, and volume selection buttons. The industrial designer mentions the need to consider the technical aspects and the cost of materials. The user interface designer suggests a locator and a sound for the remote control, and clearer symbols. The project manager mentions that teletext is not popular anymore and that the target audience is young people. A new idea is presented to make changeable covers for the remote control, which could appeal to a wider audience. The group discusses the possibility of an LCD screen, but it is decided that it would be too expensive and consume too much battery power. The group agrees on the need for a beep function and the importance of durability. The industrial designer will look into the costs and possibilities of the different ideas.

The group, consisting of Adam Duguid (Project Manager), Ebenezer Ademesoye (Marketing Expert), Tarik Rahman (Industrial Designer), and Dave Cochrane (User Interface Defin Designer), has gathered to design a new remote control that is original, trendy, and user-friendly. The project will consist of three key phases: functional, architectural, and detailed design. The group discussed potential ideas for the remote, including touch screen capabilities, controlling multiple units in a simple fashion, and incorporating gaming features with larger buttons. The remote control is projected to cost €12.50 per unit, and the group aims to sell them for €25, requiring a large number of units sold to reach their goal of €50 million. The group will focus on the user interface and functionality for their next meeting.

The Schools Challenge Cymru was a time-limited program aimed at improving 39 schools in Wales, and it has now ended with a transition to regional consortia for school improvement. The Cabinet Secretary for Education, Kirsty Williams, has had ongoing dialogue with a variety of people regarding the lessons learned from the program, but there is a perception from Professor Mel Ainscow, the figurehead of the program, that he has not been sufficiently engaged with since March of last year.

The discussion revolves around the functional design of a remote control, with the team discussing the features and user interface. There were also technical issues faced during the presentation of the design.

The group is discussing the extent and condition of schools making good use of the Pupil Deprivation Grant (PDG) funding. Kirsty Williams, the Cabinet Secretary for Education, explains that individual interventions should only be targeted at children who are eligible for free school meals, but schools may use PDG funding for universal interventions if they can demonstrate a disproportionate effect on the outcomes for children on free school meals. She also emphasizes the importance of using PDG for more able and talented children who are eligible for free school meals. The group discusses the measures in place to ensure proper use of PDG, including regional advisers and challenge advisers who provide strategic advice and challenge schools on their usage of PDG. The Cabinet Secretary acknowledges the need for more consistent practice across regions and the role of regional advisers in enabling this.

The Welsh government has been discussing the use of eligibility for free school meals as a measure for identifying and targeting pupils in need of additional support. Kirsty Williams, the Cabinet Secretary for Education, acknowledges that while it may not be a perfect measure, it is the best available proxy for identifying pupils in need. The government is also considering the impact of the roll-out of universal credit and working with the department in England to understand its implications for identifying relative need. There has been some discussion about changing the once-a-year eligibility for free school meals to a more flexible system, but this would require additional resources. The government is also looking at flexibility in the use of the Pupil Deprivation Grant (PDG) and has appointed new PDG regional advisers to spread good practice. While Estyn recognizes that PDG is being used to push more able and talented children, there are concerns about whether this is happening consistently across all schools. The government is also considering being more flexible with the definition of PDG eligibility rather than reducing the amount per head.

The meeting focused on discussing the data collection for a project. They discussed the subjects' tasks, which involve giving information about themselves and completing six different tasks related to traveling in Heidelberg. The tasks involve reading a text with German words and isolated proper names, and then interacting with a computer system that can understand and respond to their requests. The system will break down after three tasks, and a human operator will take over. The data collection will involve thirty subjects and will start tomorrow. The group also discussed the design of a belief-net for decision making and the addition of new nodes for financial state and user budget. They also discussed the level of detail for the ontology and the types of places that someone could go, with the aim of simplifying the system and focusing on a more confined set of things. The group also discussed the types of constructions that people might use when talking about different places and the need to affect those constructions through the dialogue. Robert presented a table of decision nodes and values, and the group discussed the possibility of reducing the number of decisions and values. They also discussed the need to get more data on a relatively confined set of things and the potential danger of certain constructions that might be used with different places. The Children, Young People and Education Committee discussed the draft strategy 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales' with Dr Frank Atherton, the Chief Medical Officer for Wales, and Nathan Cook, head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government. The discussion covered the strategy's focus on children and young people, engagement with this group, leadership, investment, and partnership working. The committee also discussed the clinical obesity pathway, the first 1,000 days, and support for low-income families.

The group is discussing a meeting update from Robert regarding the EDU and SmartKom projects. Robert mentions that the data collection for EDU has been successful with thirty subjects and ten dialogues transcribed. He also mentions that there have been issues with the synthesis for SmartKom, but they should be resolved. The group also discusses a visitor from Bruchsal, Andreas, who is related to the EML and is using similar technologies as the group. The group then discusses PRM (Probabilistic Relational Models) and its potential use in their work. Eva has been working on constructing classes and dependency models for PRM and is trying to see if it would make inferencing more efficient. The group also discusses the output of the PRM model, which makes two decisions: how desirable a site is and the mode of visit. The group also discusses the potential of using an interpreter for PRM and the possibility of integrating it with their existing work.

Dawn Bowden AM asked about sports infrastructure and the potential for using the planning system to restrict hot food takeaways around schools to promote physical activity. Dr. Frank Atherton, the Chief Medical Officer for Wales, supported the idea of using the planning system in this way and noted that some local authorities in the UK have already implemented similar moratoriums.

In a meeting, the group discussed adding support for DVD players to remote controls. They talked about the importance of placing laptops exactly on a marked spot and using a touch-pad instead of a mouse. They also discussed how to wake up a laptop and the use of the smart-boards and white-board for presentations. The group then drew their favorite animals using different colors and pen widths on the electronic white-boards. They discussed the objectives of the project, which are to design a new remote control that is original, trendy, and user-friendly. The group consists of a Project Manager, Marketing, User Interface Designer, and Industrial Designer. They discussed the tool training, project finance, and brainstormed ideas for the remote control. The remote control will be a television remote control, with grouped buttons for different functions and a maximum production cost of twelve Euro fifty per remote control. The group also prioritized user-friendliness and discussed making it trendy and original. The meeting ended with each member having individual tasks and the next meeting set for thirty minutes later.

The discussion focused on why children on free school meals were less resilient in the exam system last year. Kirsty Williams, the Cabinet Secretary for Education, acknowledged that the attainment gap between children on free school meals and those not on free school meals has widened, but she noted that there has been a narrowing of the gap over the period that the Pupil Deprivation Grant (PDG) has been employed. She mentioned that the use of PDG is evolving and becoming more effective over time, with schools understanding how best to deploy the money for best effect for students. She also mentioned that leadership within individual schools plays a crucial role in the effective use of PDG. The Cabinet Secretary acknowledged that there is still work to do to ensure that all schools are employing best practice and that the new regional advisers are going to be crucial in enabling the government to ensure more consistent practice across the regions. She was asked if eligibility for free school meals is the best measure to identify which pupils to target, and she responded that it is probably the best measure available, but they are open to discussions with local government about different ways to identify relative need. She was also asked about the flexibility of PDG and the once-a-year eligibility for free school meals, and she mentioned that they are actively looking at that and considering greater flexibility and maybe longer-term projections.

Dr. Frank Atherton, the Chief Medical Officer for Wales, and Nathan Cook, head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government, discussed the 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales' draft strategy with the Children, Young People and Education Committee. Dr. Atherton expressed confidence that the all-age strategy will deliver for children and young people, and discussed engagement with children and young people to inform the draft strategy. He also discussed leadership and the potential for a target to reduce obesity among children, as well as investment needed to implement the plan. The conversation also covered data availability and metrics for measuring progress, and potential measures such as restricting price promotions and banning energy drinks. Additionally, the planning system and community sport infrastructure were discussed as possible tools for promoting healthy weight in children.

Dr. Frank Atherton, the Chief Medical Officer for Wales, and Nathan Cook, head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government, discussed the 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales' draft strategy during a Children, Young People and Education Committee meeting. Dr. Atherton expressed confidence that the all-age strategy would deliver for children and young people, and discussed engagement with children and young people to inform the draft strategy. Nathan Cook mentioned the production of a toolkit to encourage schools and youth groups to contribute to the consultation. Dr. Atherton discussed the possibility of setting a target for reducing obesity among children, and mentioned the importance of evaluation and resourcing for the plan's implementation. Sian Gwenllian AM asked about leadership and investment for the plan, and Dr. Atherton mentioned the potential use of revenue from the levy on soft drinks for efforts to reduce childhood obesity. The discussion also covered data collection and partnership working for the plan's implementation.

Dr. Frank Atherton, the Chief Medical Officer for Wales, and Nathan Cook, head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government, discussed the 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales' draft strategy during a Children, Young People and Education Committee meeting. Dr. Atherton expressed confidence in the strategy's ability to deliver for children and young people, emphasizing the need to focus on the next generation to prevent the current high prevalence of overweight and obesity from continuing. He mentioned that the strategy has engaged with children and young people through various forums, including schools and a young person who attended the joint launch on the consultation. Nathan Cook added that they have produced a toolkit to encourage schools and youth groups to contribute to the consultation. Sian Gwenllian AM asked about leadership and targets in the strategy, to which Dr. Atherton replied that they may consider a target but are currently consulting on the issue, and that performance management and evaluation are crucial components of the strategy. Dr. Atherton also mentioned that the level of investment needed to implement the plan is still being assessed, and that existing programs will be evaluated for effectiveness and value.

In a meeting, the team discussed the prototype of a new remote control. The remote has a snail shape and is blue with yellow buttons. It is compact, fits well in the hand, and has a special case made of strong plastic and soft rubber buttons. The remote includes a voice recognizer, a menu button, and buttons for controlling the picture on the screen. The marketing expert believes the remote will be sellable due to its ease of use and attractive design. The team is considering adding more features to the remote, but they need to ensure they stay within budget, as the voice recognizer will be an additional cost.

The group discussed the effects of room noise and reverberation on audio recordings, and how it can impact the dynamic range and quantization error. They talked about a simple filter suggested by Dan Ellis to run over the data before processing it. The use of high-pass filtering and pre-emphasis in the STRUT implementation was also discussed. They also talked about the latency reduction plan and the possibility of using a second stream for processing. The next meeting is scheduled for June. Additionally, they discussed the use of different VADs (Voice Activity Detectors) and how the French VAD performed better than the baseline set of features. Hynek will be back in town the week after next to organize more visits and connections.

At a meeting, the team discussed the design of a new remote control that should be original, trendy, user-friendly, multi-functional, and affordable to produce. They came up with ideas for its design, functionality, and features, including the possibility of a light or sound signal when the remote is lost. The next step is to create a working design and user requirement specifications, and the team will reconvene in thirty minutes to continue the discussion.

In the last meeting, the industrial designer presented the design for a new remote control. The remote will have a child-friendly design with few buttons, and an oversized version is also being considered. The designer also suggested incorporating speech recognition technology into the remote. The marketing expert suggested that the remote should be small, easy to use, eye-catching, and have a fruit and vegetable design with a soft feel. The team decided to focus on one or two key features for the remote, such as a speech recognizer, and to prioritize getting to market before competitors. The prototype of the remote was presented, featuring a snail shape, blue and yellow color scheme, and soft rubber buttons. The remote will have a fluorescent green LED and include buttons for various functions such as channel control, volume control, and a menu button. The team also discussed the importance of symbols on the buttons for international markets. The remote will have a holder in the shape of a snail shell. The marketing expert will present a production evaluation in the next meeting. The team is currently within budget, but there is concern about finding room for the voice recognizer feature in the financing.

The project manager welcomes everyone to the conceptual design meeting and reviews the agenda. The minutes from the previous meeting were not fully legible due to technical difficulties, but the project manager will use a keyboard instead of a pen to type the minutes moving forward. The industrial designer presents the components design of the remote control, discussing the materials and energy sources. The user interface designer mentions the need to gather user requirements, but the project manager believes they decided on basic functions in the last meeting. The group discusses the design and functionality of the remote control, including the number and type of buttons.

The team discussed the merits and demerits of existing remotes in a meeting. Raj presented trends that will affect market potential and how important design and technological innovation are for remote controls. The team found that people prefer fancy remote controls with a good design over functional ones. The most important factor in designing remote controls is the outlook, which is twice as important as the second factor and three times as important as the third factor. The second most important aspect is that remote controls should be technologically innovative, and the third most important aspect is that they should be easy to use. The team also discussed incorporating fruit and vegetable themes into the design, making the remote control spongy, and using rubber that is good for health and disposable. They also talked about having a fancy design with a spongy feel and making it easy for customers to understand the manual in their local language. The team also discussed the possibility of using speech recognition technology in the remote control.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee had a meeting to discuss the draft strategy of 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales'. The Chief Medical Officer for Wales, Dr Frank Atherton, and Nathan Cook, head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government, were present. Dr Atherton expressed confidence that the strategy will deliver for children and young people. He mentioned that they have discussed with young people in various forums and have had good input from them. Nathan Cook added that they have also produced a toolkit to engage schools and youth groups in the consultation process. Dr Atherton mentioned that they are considering the possibility of setting a target to reduce obesity among children, but it is not certain yet. He also mentioned that the level of investment needed to implement the plan has not been assessed yet, but it will depend on the actions that will be taken. Sian Gwenllian asked about the emphasis on whole-system approach in implementing the plan and how they will coordinate action and drive change across relevant partners. Dr Atherton mentioned that they will need some sort of structure to lead this and that leadership will be important. He also mentioned that they will need to make existing programmes more effective and there may be a case for new investment.

The team is discussing the design of a new remote control. They want it to be original, trendy, and easy to use. They are considering making it a universal remote and adding a tracking device to prevent losing it. They are also considering giving the remote a ball shape and making it out of sturdy materials to withstand being thrown around.

The EAS consortium's approach to using the PDG for looked-after and adopted children is part of a broader approach targeted at vulnerable learners. The Cabinet Secretary for Education, Kirsty Williams, supports this approach, stating that if interventions can be successful for vulnerable learners, they will benefit all learners. She also mentions the importance of a multi-agency approach to supporting children, especially those at risk of exclusion. The Cabinet Secretary acknowledges the disparity in attendance rates between free school meal and non-free school meal pupils and mentions schools using PDG to address this issue. She gives examples of schools proactively addressing attendance issues, such as sending teaching assistants out in the morning to create a walking bus and accompany children to breakfast clubs. The Cabinet Secretary also mentions the link between attendance and attainment, stating that unless children are in class, it will be difficult to close the attainment gap. She notes that while there has been an improvement in attendance rates over time, there is still a gap between free school meal and non-free school meal pupils. The Cabinet Secretary mentions that the use of PDG is evolving and becoming more sophisticated, with schools understanding how best to deploy the money for maximum impact. She also mentions that the PDG is probably the best example of schools following evidence-based interventions to deploy money. The Cabinet Secretary states that the majority of schools are making well thought out and appropriate decisions on how to use PDG, but Estyn reports that only two-thirds of primary and secondary schools make effective use of the PDG. She mentions that this may be due to leadership within individual schools and that improving capacity in leadership and developing leadership talent in the Welsh education system is a key priority for her. The Cabinet Secretary also mentions that the use of PDG is evolving over time and that schools are increasingly learning to tailor approaches in their schools based on research and intelligence, both in Wales and outside of Wales. She notes that the changing use of PDG reflects the journeys that schools have been on, from spending money on infrastructure to actual inputs in terms of teaching and learning. The Cabinet Secretary also mentions that the Sutton Trust toolkit is being used to demonstrate an evidence base for PDG usage and that schools are being challenged to demonstrate their evidence base and impact justification for using the money.

Grad A, Grad C, and Grad D discuss a meeting they had where they tested a wizard system. They talk about the difficulties of the reading task and suggest making the introduction better and shortening the reading time. They also discuss the possibility of hiring Fey and putting her on the payroll. Grad A presents a pedagogical belief-net that groups things according to image schemas. They discuss the possibility of using Noisy-OR's and Noisy-MAXes to avoid a combinatoric input to the Mode thing. They also talk about the M-3-L system and how it can be integrated into the existing SmartKom system. The conversation shifts to the cognitive dispatcher module and how it can be useful for rewriting and getting parts of the system. The conversation ends with a discussion about the Bayes-nets and how they will be decision-specific for each decision.

A meeting is being summarized where a group of researchers are discussing their work on various speech recognition projects. Professor C mentions that a colleague, Hans Guenter, will be visiting for three weeks to look at their work and possibly collaborate. Graduate student E is working on implementing spectral subtraction in the SmartKom system and has been testing different window sizes for calculating the mean. They discuss the potential impact of having less than the desired window size for calculation and the implications for word error rates. The group also discusses the use of filters and the idea of caching utterances in a system for improved performance. PhD A suggests having users introduce themselves before using the system to improve adaptations. Professor C brings up the idea of a second pass in the system for improved processing. The group discusses different techniques for noise estimation and the use of VAD (Voice Activity Detection) for improving performance. They also discuss the use of spectral subtraction and Wiener filtering in speech recognition systems and the challenges associated with each. The group also talks about the importance of the VAD system and the potential for further improvements in this area.

In a meeting, the team discussed the conceptual design of a remote control. They decided not to use speech recognition technology and were undecided about using an LCD screen due to costs. They also discussed the possibility of using fruit-themed designs, such as a banana-shaped remote control. The team was tasked with creating a prototype based on the meeting's decisions for the next meeting.

In a group discussion about the target group and corresponding functionalities for a product, the project manager presents the agenda and takes notes. The group discusses the target customers and the functionality of the product. Marketing has conducted research on user habits and preferences regarding remote controls, which shows that users want a remote control that looks nice and is easy to use, with buttons that are matched to their usage behavior. The industrial designer will consider these factors in the functional and user interface design. The group aims to reach a decision about the target group and functionality in this meeting.

The project manager is summarizing the previous meeting's discussion. In the last meeting, the user interface designer presented the importance of the look of the new remote control for a TV. The remote should have nine channel buttons, a next button, volume buttons, subtitle buttons, a mute button, a memory switch, and a speech recognition feature. The industrial designer suggested using a special case made out of plastic, with an integrated circuit board and a rechargeable battery. The marketing expert wants the remote to be small, easy to use, eye-catching, and trendy, with a fruit and vegetable design and a soft feel. The team decided that the special feature of the remote should be a speech recognizer, and the prototype of the remote is presented. The remote is in a snail shape, blue in color, with yellow buttons. The case is made of plastic and the buttons are made of soft rubber. The remote also has a fluorescent green LED and an infrared light emitting diode. The button part of the remote is explained by the user interface designer. The remote includes a switch on and off button, a mute button, one to nine buttons for controlling the programs, two buttons for increasing or decreasing the volume, two buttons for scrolling up and down the channels, a menu button, and a swapping button. The remote also has an inbuilt voice recognizer. The marketing expert likes the prototype, especially its one-thumb usability and the prominent placement of the on-off button. The team discusses whether to include text or symbols on the buttons, and they decide to include symbols to make the remote suitable for an international market. The team also discusses the production evaluation and financing of the project.

Marketing, Industrial Design, and the Project Manager are discussing the functional requirements of a remote control for a television. They discuss the possibility of including an LCD screen, the importance of low power usage, and the desire to make the remote control usable for more than one appliance. They also consider the preferences of different age groups, with younger people more interested in advanced features and elderly people preferring a simpler design. The group decides to focus on a user-centered approach and to include basic functions such as power, volume, and channel control. They also discuss the importance of making the remote control easy to use and find, with buttons that are not too small or complex.

The meeting is about discussing the progress of a project. The project manager will present the agenda and take notes during the meeting. The group will discuss the target audience and functionality of the project. The marketing expert has conducted research on user habits and preferences regarding remote controls. The group will also discuss the possibility of incorporating speech recognition technology into the remote control. The industrial designer will consider the research and data when working on the user interface and functional design. The group will aim to reach a decision on the target audience and functionality of the project during the meeting. After the meeting, the group will have lunch together.

A group is discussing the design of a remote control for a television. They discuss the possibility of using an LCD screen, the buttons and functions it should have, and the potential use of speech recognition. They consider the needs of different age groups and the importance of making the remote easy to use. They also discuss the possibility of using rechargeable batteries and a docking station. The group decides to prioritize an LCD screen, with buttons for volume, channel selection, and digits, as well as a mute button and a separate menu for teletext. They also plan to include a battery indicator and the possibility of enlarging buttons for elderly users. If there is enough money left in the budget, they will consider adding speech recognition and making the remote available in different colors.

In a meeting, the group discussed video demand, teletext demand, and thick keys design for a remote control. The marketing team presented research on user preferences for remote control features, including a desire for fancier looking remotes and a dislike for current remote designs. The industrial designer presented their preferences for the technical components of the remote control, focusing on reliability and functionality. The group discussed the possibility of including speech recognition technology in the remote control and the potential demographics for the product. The project manager shared thoughts from the account manager, including the idea of a more universal remote control with a lower price point. The group decided to target the 20-40 age group and create a universal remote control with a price point of 12.50 Euros. The next steps include determining the necessary components and user interface content for the universal remote control and researching trends in this market.

In this meeting, the team discussed and evaluated a new product design, which is a remote control in the shape of a fruit. Professor B and others are discussing the issue of a voice activity detector (VAD) in the context of the Aurora program, a speech recognition project. They are discussing the impact of using a VAD on the performance of speech recognition systems and the potential issues with modifying the weights of different systems. The group is also discussing the properties of vectors in temporal pattern recognition, specifically the correlation and distribution of elements in the vector. They are considering the use of multiple critical bands and the conversion of energy over time in a particular frequency band into a vector of numbers. The group is also discussing the potential benefits and drawbacks of adding noise to all data as a way to make the training data more uniform. They are also discussing the use of all-pole models for spectral analysis. Additionally, they are discussing the TRAPS recognition system, which recognizes speech based on time trajectories of energy at a given frequency, and the potential benefits and challenges of this approach. The group is also discussing the next evaluation for the Aurora program and the potential for people to have made progress since the last evaluation.

Dr. David Blaney, Chief Executive of the Higher Education Funding Council for Wales, was asked about the impact of Brexit on Wales' higher education system during a meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee. Blaney said uncertainty about relationships and arrangements with Europe is one of the most significant issues confronting university management, and the sector is exposed to EU-sourced income such as EU students, structural funds, and EU research funding. There are signs of decreased applications from EU students and increased difficulties in playing in EU collaborative research activities. The financial impact of Brexit is hard to predict, but some money from the UK's net contribution to the EU may be available back to the UK, and the extent to which Wales benefits will depend on political relationships. Bethan Owen, Director of Institutional Engagement, added that the main pressures on the Welsh higher education sector include the funding position, student recruitment, pay and pension costs, increased student expectations for modern facilities, and uncertainty about potential consequences from the review of fees and funding in England. In terms of European Union students and enrolment, Wales is not forecast to do as well as England, and this may be due to changes in student support arrangements and the relative levels of investment in facilities between Wales and England. The committee also discussed the potential impacts of Brexit on research funding and collaborations.

The text is a transcript of a meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee of the National Assembly for Wales. The committee is discussing the impact of Brexit on higher and further education in Wales. The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales is giving evidence, represented by Dr David Blaney, Chief Executive, and Bethan Owen, Director of Institutional Engagement. They discuss the potential impact of Brexit on Welsh higher education, including the exposure of the sector to EU-sourced income and the potential effects on student recruitment and research collaborations. They also discuss the financial pressures on the Welsh higher education sector, including the implementation of the Diamond recommendations and the challenges of student recruitment and pay and pension costs. The committee members ask questions about the decrease in EU and non-EU student applications to Welsh universities and the reasons behind this trend. The witnesses also discuss the potential impact of Brexit on European Union students and enrolment in Welsh universities, and the challenges of planning for the financial implications of Brexit. The discussion also covers the importance of marketing and promoting Wales as a good place to study, and the need to differentiate the strengths of Wales to attract international students. The witnesses also mention the importance of maintaining infrastructure and resources in the short term, and the need for confidence in the forecasts and long-term future funding prospects to enable the sector to return to longer-term financial sustainability.

The text is a transcript of a meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee in Wales. The committee is discussing the impact of Brexit on higher and further education in Wales. The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales is present to give evidence. The committee asks about the evidence seen so far of Brexit's impact, and the CEO of the council, Dr David Blaney, responds that it is difficult to separate the impact of Brexit from other factors. He mentions uncertainty about relationships and arrangements with Europe as a significant issue for university management. The committee also asks about the main pressures on the Welsh higher education sector, and Bethan Owen, Director of Institutional Engagement, mentions the funding position and student recruitment as the main pressures. She also mentions pay and pension costs, increased student expectations for modern facilities, and uncertainty about potential consequences from the review of fees and funding in England. The committee asks about European Union students and enrolment, and Bethan Owen mentions a decrease in applications from EU students and non-EU students to Welsh institutions. The committee asks about the reasons for this decrease, and Dr David Blaney mentions changes in student support arrangements and the relative levels of investment between Wales and England as possible reasons. The committee also asks about the financial forecasts for the next few years, and Bethan Owen mentions that the sector is expecting to receive a full forecast at the end of the month. The committee asks about the universities' plans for capital investment, and Bethan Owen mentions that they are all planning for capital investment but are facing challenges in borrowing from financial institutions. The committee asks about the clarity from the Welsh Government about how much they anticipate the Diamond dividend will be and what proportion of that is going to be released to HEIs in the future, and Bethan Owen mentions that it is difficult to give a clear answer due to the annual remit letter and the budgetary process.
