The Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill aims to prohibit all forms of physical punishment of children to protect their rights and ensure they have the same protection as adults. The Bill has received opposition from 70% of individuals who responded to a written consultation and many parents who met with the committee. The Deputy Minister for Health and Social Services, Julie Morgan, emphasized the importance of the Bill in protecting children's rights and ensuring that physical punishment is not used as a way of disciplining children. She acknowledged the concerns of parents but believes that there are better ways to discipline children without resorting to physical punishment. The Bill does not create a new offence but removes the defence of reasonable punishment for common assault. An implementation group has been set up to address issues related to the Bill, and four work streams have been established to look at parenting advice and support, data collection, evaluation and monitoring, operations, procedures and processes, and out-of-court disposals and diversions. The committee discussed the potential impact of the Bill on social services, the police, and CAFCASS and the need for data collection and monitoring to assess its effectiveness.

The team discussed the possibility of using a microphone array, but it was deemed too expensive. The final decision was to go with the version without the LCD screen, as it is more robust and easier to use. The team also discussed the possibility of using customizable skins for the remote control. The meeting concluded with positive feedback on the team's creativity, leadership, and teamwork.

The evaluation criteria included staying under a budget of twelve and a half Euros. The design is accessible with the other hand and has a panel that can be hidden with rubber layers. The bumps on the remote control serve an added effect and artistic purpose. The remote control is designed to stay in balance and lie in the hand like an old telephone. The team also discussed the color options, with basic colors like white or metallic grey for a broader public and the possibility of making covers exchangeable. A wooden style cover was also suggested. The remote control is aimed primarily at younger people, but the team agreed to make the standard model more adult-friendly with flashy fruity colors. The team also discussed the possibility of developing a cover without a cover for customers to choose in the store. The Marketing Expert then evaluated the prototype concept according to past user requirements and trends analysis using a seven-point scale. The team discussed and voted on each requirement, such as the remote control being designed for people under forty, having big, clear channel switching buttons, and being easy to find. The team also discussed the production costs and how to stay under the budget of twelve and a half Euros.

The prototype presentation is given by G\_ and G\_ focusing on a single touch-screen remote control concept with a form that is easy to hold and buttons accessible with the thumb. The design includes a panel that can be hidden with rubber layers and a top and front view with two bumps for added effect and balance. The remote control is designed to stay in place when placed on a table and has a layer over the panel that is curved. The remote control is designed to appeal to a broad public with exchangeable covers and young people can choose from various hip colors while older people may prefer more traditional colors. The marketing team suggests selling the remote control without a cover so that users can choose one in the store. The team then evaluates the prototype according to past user requirements and trends analysis using a seven-point scale and group decision making. The remote control is designed for people of all ages and is considered beautiful and fancy. The remote control has big, clear channel switching buttons but no teletext buttons as teletext is in the menu. The remote control is easy to find due to its shape and color, and it has fresh, fruity colors. The remote control is made of soft material and is easy to use. The team then calculates the production cost and finds that it is under the budget of twelve and a half Euros. The team also discusses the possibility of adding a parental advisory function and a docking station for rechargeable batteries. The team then discusses the leadership and creativity in the meetings, with some team members feeling that there was not enough room for creativity and that the leadership was crappy. The team also discusses the use of a digital pen and finds that it is not user-friendly and takes too much time to draw and write things. The team suggests improving the software to make it quicker and more user-friendly.

A meeting was held to discuss the creation of a new television remote control with original, trendy, and user-friendly characteristics. The team discussed the design aspects, the role of each member, and the challenges they might face in gathering information for browsing content. It was decided that the functional design aspect would be discussed further in a subsequent meeting.

In a meeting, the team discussed Marketing's presentation on three important marketing points for a remote control product. They decided on using a simple battery as the energy source, a rubber double curved case, and basic push-buttons for the interface. The team also talked about the product's image, aiming for it to be different, fun, and user-friendly, possibly with various color options.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee had a meeting to discuss the Welsh baccalaureate qualification with Kirsty Williams AM, Cabinet Secretary for Education, Kevin Palmer, deputy director of pedagogy, leadership and professional learning, and Andrew Clark, deputy director of further education and apprenticeships division. Kirsty Williams values the qualification and believes it helps ensure a broad and balanced curriculum for young people in Wales. She acknowledges that there have been concerns raised about the qualification, including workload issues for teachers and students, and the impact of the qualification on students' well-being. She believes that there is room for improvement and that the review conducted by Qualifications Wales will help identify ways to further improve and refine the qualification. The Cabinet Secretary values the qualification highly and thinks it is a valuable piece of work for Welsh young people to undertake. Julie Morgan AM asked about the value of the baccalaureate and Kirsty Williams responded that she believes it helps ensure a broad and balanced curriculum, recognizing the need to develop knowledge and skills in core subjects, as well as preparing students for further study and the world of work. She noted that many young people and teachers have had positive experiences studying for the Welsh bac and that it is valued by universities and employers. However, she acknowledged that there is a job of work to be done to communicate the value of the qualification to those who are not familiar with it. She also mentioned that there have been concerns raised about the workload associated with the qualification and that Qualifications Wales has conducted a review to identify ways to improve and refine it.

The team, including an industrial designer, user interface designer, and marketing representative, are starting a project to create a new remote control that is original, trendy, and user-friendly. The project will be divided into three parts: functional design, conceptual design, and detailed design. During the kick-off meeting, the team discussed their experiences using remote controls, features they like and dislike, and ideas for the new remote control.

In a meeting, the team discusses the design of a TV remote control. They decide on a rubber case, simple push-buttons, and a basic battery as the power source. They also consider making the remote charge through kinetic energy generated by squeezing it. The team agrees that the remote should be easy to use and visually appealing, possibly incorporating bright, natural colors. They plan to market it as user-friendly and suitable for families with young children. Catherine will work on the look and feel design, Gabriel on the user interface design, and the marketing team will handle product evaluation and promotion. The team is motivated by the potential for profit sharing on the product.

In a meeting, the team discussed the presentation on the energy source and case material design of a remote control by an Industrial Designer. The Marketing team expressed their excitement about the remote control, comparing it to a fashion accessory. The Industrial Designer explained the options for the energy source, including batteries, a hand dynamo, kinetic provision of energy, and solar cells. The team discussed the case material options, including plastic, latex rubber, wood, and titanium, and their compatibility with different case shapes and energy sources. They decided on a rubber double curved case and basic battery as the energy source. The team also discussed the push-buttons, with options including basic push-buttons, scroll-wheels, and LCD with display and scroll buttons. They decided on rubber push-buttons for the rubber double curved case. The Industrial Designer will create prototypes for the next meeting.

The presentation is about two versions of a prototype for a remote control. The first version has an LCD display and a speech recognition system, while the second version does not have an LCD display and has a different button configuration. Both versions come with a charger and have a detachable control module and big buttons. The prototype with the LCD display is estimated to cost around fifteen dollars, while the other version is estimated to cost around four dollars. The team discussed the potential for a microphone array, but it was determined to be too expensive. The remote controls are designed to be modular, so customers can add or remove functions as needed. The team also discussed the potential for a "find the charger" button and the use of rechargeable batteries. The remote controls are designed to be simple and powerful, with few buttons but all the necessary controls. The team also discussed the potential for additional modules for parental control and accessibility for older users. The remote controls are designed to be customizable and easy to use, with a focus on technological innovation and a fancy look and feel. The team used a seven-point scale to evaluate the remote controls in terms of fancy look, innovativeness, and ease of use. The remote controls were rated as a three for fancy look with the LCD display and a four without, and a five for innovativeness with or without the LCD display. The team recommended going forward with the version without the LCD display, as it is simpler, easier to use, and cheaper to produce. The team also discussed the potential for customizable skins for the remote controls. The presentation ended with the team expressing satisfaction with the project and discussing the potential for celebration.

The group discussed a presentation on a prototype of a remote control designed to look like a banana, including its design features such as a base station, scroll wheels, and a turbo button that also serves as an on/off switch. They also evaluated the product's potential market and cost, and discussed the possibility of adding more features in future versions.

In this meeting, the team discusses the conceptual design for a new remote control device. The Project Manager summarizes the minutes from the previous meeting, during which they discussed marketing research and initial design ideas. Sarah, the marketing representative, presents her findings on the current cost of competition, which ranges from twenty to sixty Euros. She also discusses trends in the remote control market, suggesting that organic, fruit-themed designs and technologically innovative, yet easy-to-use devices are popular. Steph, the user interface designer, agrees with Sarah's suggestions and adds that ease of use is a top priority for consumers. Kate, the industrial designer, presents her ideas for a simple, mass-produced device with rechargeable batteries and a docking station. The team agrees that the target market is fifteen to thirty-five-year-olds with more money than sense, who are decision-makers or manufacturers looking to enclose the remote with a TV. They decide that Sarah will research the cost of competition, Steph will look into ergonomics, Kate will explore cost and feasibility, and the Project Manager will type up the minutes and work on the final report.

In a meeting, the team discussed the prototype of a remote control. The prototype comes with a charger and a detachable control module. There are two versions of the prototype, one with an LCD and one without, due to the expense of LCDs. Both versions come with detachable big buttons. The LCD version has a joystick-like button for navigation and a microphone for speech recognition. The switch for the speech recognition system is placed on the side, which was questioned by the project manager. The team discussed the cost of the prototype, which is fifteen dollars, but they aim to reduce it to ten dollars in production. The remote control uses two AA rechargeable batteries. The team also discussed the idea of a kinetic reserve, but it was not finalized. The LCD version has a whole day rating of 24 hours. The remote control is modular, so customers can add or remove functions as they want, which will affect the price. The team also discussed the idea of parental control modules. The remote control is designed to be simple and powerful, with few buttons and advanced functionalities. The team also discussed the idea of making the remote control in the shape of fruits or vegetables, and making it spongy. The team agreed to propose customers with skins instead of changing the entire shape. The team also discussed the project evaluation and was satisfied with the results. The team also discussed the leadership, teamwork, and new ideas found during the project. The team agreed to bring more snacks to meetings and to have clear points for discussion. The project manager thanked the team for their work and suggested celebrating with free coffee.

The group discussed the final design of a remote control in the shape of a banana. They presented the prototype, which includes a base station, two scroll wheels for volume and channel control, and a turbo button for quick channel switching. They also discussed the use of the turbo button as an on/off switch and a teletext button. The group evaluated the design based on criteria such as functionality, ease of use, and cool features, and determined that it is a promising product despite not being universally popular among the group members.

The project manager is leading a meeting to discuss the final design of a remote control shaped like a banana. The team presents the prototype, which includes a base station with a banana leaf design and a remote with scroll wheels and a trigger-like button for skipping channels. The remote also has a teletext button that changes the function of the other buttons when pressed. The team discusses the use of solar cells for power, but ultimately decides against it. They also discuss the potential market for the product and the need for further evaluation. The meeting concludes with the team discussing the possibility of adding more features to the remote in the future.

The Welsh Government discussed policies and measures related to free-school-meal children during the pandemic, emphasizing the importance of supporting vulnerable and continuing education. The Government plans to finalize these plans with partners in local government, focusing on supporting and safeguarding the vulnerable and ensuring continuity of learning.

The Welsh Government is working to ensure the continuity of education during the coronavirus pandemic, with schools taking on a new purpose to support vulnerable children and those of key workers, and provide continuity of learning. The Government is also working on a plan to award fair grades to students who were due to sit exams, and has cancelled the summer exam series.

Kirsty Williams AM, the Minister for Education in Wales, discussed the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales during a virtual meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee. The meeting was held remotely due to public health concerns, with all participants joining via video conference. The main topic of discussion was the reopening of schools, with the Minister emphasizing that it will not be imminent and will depend on the advice of medical and scientific experts. The Minister also outlined five principles that will guide her decision-making process, including the safety and well-being of children, young people, and staff, clear communication, and practical considerations such as social distancing and transportation. The Minister also mentioned that the principles apply to further education and universities, and that the Welsh Government is working closely with representatives of those sectors.

The Welsh Government discussed issues related to the potential closures of colleges and universities due to the coronavirus pandemic. The Minister for Education, Kirsty Williams, announced that summer exams for GCSE, AS, and A-levels have been cancelled, and students will be awarded a fair grade based on available information. The Government is working to ensure continuity of education and support for vulnerable students, and schools will remain open to provide a safe and secure place for children of key workers and those who benefit from free school meals.

Kirsty Williams AM, the Welsh Minister for Education, discussed the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales during a virtual meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee. She expressed gratitude for the efforts of school staff in keeping schools open for vulnerable children and children of key workers, and thanked parents for keeping their children at home to reduce pressure on the education system and NHS. The Minister emphasized that the health and well-being of children, young people, and staff in education settings is her primary concern. She outlined five principles that will guide her decision on when schools might reopen, including considering the safety and well-being of children, young people, and staff, and building confidence for parents and professionals by communicating information used to reach decisions. The Minister also mentioned that they are working on a four-nation basis and looking at best international evidence to plan for the future. She confirmed that these principles apply to both schools and further education colleges, and they are working closely with the higher education sector.

The Welsh Government is taking steps to ensure the continuity of education during the COVID-19 pandemic, including closing schools and developing plans to support vulnerable children and ensure continued learning. The Government is also working on a plan to award fair grades to students who were supposed to take exams, which have been cancelled.

The Welsh Government discussed ideas about timescales for handling the lack of exams due to the coronavirus pandemic. The Education Minister, Kirsty Williams, announced that the summer exam series will not proceed, and learners due to sit these exams will be awarded a fair grade. The Welsh Government is working to develop and finalize plans to support vulnerable children and ensure continuity of learning. Schools in Wales already have access to digital tools for distance learning, and a guide on what tools are available and how schools can use them has been developed. The Government is also working on emergency legislation to provide powers to temporarily close schools or other educational institutions, give temporary continuity directions, and direct resources. The Government is considering relaxing requirements around ratios in childcare settings and rules around the level of nutrition that schools should be giving their children.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee of the Welsh Government held a virtual meeting to discuss the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales. Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning, attended the meeting. The Minister expressed gratitude to all those who have been working hard to keep schools open for the children of key workers and vulnerable children. She mentioned that the primary concern is the health and well-being of children, young people, and staff in education settings. The Minister also highlighted the challenges faced by the education system due to the pandemic and thanked parents and carers for their efforts in keeping their children at home. The committee discussed the principles that will guide the decision on when and how to reopen schools, including the safety and well-being of children and staff, clear communication, and careful planning. The Minister mentioned that a return to normal is not imminent and that a phased return, starting with the most vulnerable children, is likely. The committee also discussed the importance of testing in the next phase of the Government's response to the pandemic.

The Welsh Government has decided to close all schools and shift to online learning due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The decision to cancel summer exams was also made, with students being awarded grades based on available information and a modulated system across the UK.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee of the Welsh Government held a virtual meeting to discuss the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales. Minister for Education Kirsty Williams, Steve Davies, and Huw Morris attended the meeting. The Minister expressed gratitude to those keeping schools open for vulnerable children and children of key workers, and thanked parents for their efforts in home schooling. The Minister's primary concern is the health and well-being of children, young people, and staff in education settings. The Minister outlined five principles that will guide her decision on when schools might reopen, including considering the safety and well-being of children, young people, and staff, building confidence for parents and professionals, and addressing practical issues such as social distancing and school transport. The Minister also mentioned that they are working on a four-nation basis and looking at best international evidence in this regard. The Minister was asked about the principles applying to further education and universities, to which she replied that they are working with colleagues in the FE sector and in close contact with colleagues in higher education to share thinking on these matters. The Minister also mentioned that universities, as independent institutions, they wouldn't be able to dictate to, but they are working with representatives of the HE sector to include them in this work.

The group is discussing a newsflash they received about a remote control redesign project, which includes new features like an LCD screen and speech recognition. They are trying to determine the target age group for the new product and what functions should be included in the remote control.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee of the Welsh Government held a virtual meeting to discuss the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales. Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning, attended the meeting. The Minister expressed gratitude to all those who have been working hard to keep schools open for the children of key workers and vulnerable children, and to those who have been supporting learning at home. She emphasized that the health and well-being of children, young people, and staff in education settings is her primary concern. The Minister outlined five principles that will guide her decision on when schools might reopen, including considering the safety and well-being of children, young people, and staff, taking a wider view of the Welsh Government's response to the pandemic, communicating clearly with parents and staff, making decisions based on evidence, and considering which groups of children should return to school first and how to operationalize that. She also mentioned that the principles apply to further education and higher education, and that the Welsh Government is working closely with representatives of the HE sector. The Minister confirmed that schools will not be relaxing any issues around schools at present, nor is that imminent. She also mentioned that returning to school will not be a return to normal, and that the Government will seek to reduce the burdens on schools, including data collection, performance measures, and testing. The Minister also answered questions about the current situation in schools, the number of children and staff attending school hubs, the safety of staff and children, testing of school staff, and the importance of testing in the next phase of the Government's response to the pandemic.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee held an evidence session with the Welsh Government to discuss the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on education in Wales. Kirsty Williams, Minister for Education, discussed the closure of schools and the new purpose they will serve in supporting those most in need, including front-line response workers and vulnerable children. The Welsh Government is working to ensure continuity of learning for all students, including those who benefit from free school meals and have additional learning needs. All maintained schools in Wales have access to digital tools through the Hwb digital learning platform, which includes virtual classrooms and video-conferencing facilities. The Welsh Government has announced that the summer exam series will not proceed, and learners due to sit these exams will be awarded a fair grade to recognize their work. The Welsh Government is also working to ensure the continuity of childcare and early years settings, and will continue to pay for childcare delivered under the childcare offer even when a child is unable to attend.

The Welsh Government discussed the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales during a virtual meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee. Kirsty Williams, Minister for Education, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning, attended the meeting. The Minister expressed gratitude towards school staff, key workers, and parents for their efforts during the pandemic. Hefin David asked about the reopening of schools, to which the Minister replied that it will depend on the advice of the Chief Medical Officer and Chief Scientific Officer. The Minister also mentioned five principles that will guide her decision on reopening schools. Sian Gwenllian raised concerns about reopening schools without sufficient testing in place, to which the Minister reassured that schools will not reopen until it is safe to do so. The Minister also mentioned that the arrangements for school absences will be considered and reduced during this phased return. The Minister also discussed the number of children and staff attending school hubs, the safety measures in place, and the number of staff tested for COVID-19. The Minister also mentioned that the guidance for school counselling will include telephone and video support. The Minister also discussed the challenges faced by children with additional learning needs and the support available to them. The Minister also mentioned that the attainment gap between disadvantaged pupils and their more affluent peers is a concern, and the Government is looking into ways to ensure that all children have equal access to learning. The Minister also mentioned that parents are expected to contact their local education authority if they have concerns about their child's education.

The Welsh Government discussed problems and advice concerning vulnerable learners during the coronavirus pandemic. The Minister for Education, Kirsty Williams, stated that the decision to close schools was necessary to ensure public safety, and schools will support vulnerable children and ensure continuity of learning. All maintained schools in Wales have access to digital tools for distance learning through the Hwb platform. Learners due to sit exams will be awarded a fair grade. The new purpose of schools is to support those most in need, including key workers' children and vulnerable children. Work is underway to develop and finalize these plans, with a focus on supporting and safeguarding vulnerable children and ensuring continuity of learning.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee had a meeting to discuss the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on education in Wales. Kirsty Williams, the Minister for Education, and other officials were in attendance. The Minister discussed the closure of schools and the new purpose they will serve in supporting those most in need, including front-line response workers and children who benefit from free school meals and have additional learning needs. The decision to cancel summer exams was also discussed, with the Minister stating that learners will be awarded a fair grade based on available information. The Minister thanked everyone working in education settings for their hard work during this time.

1. Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education in Wales, along with other officials, attended a virtual meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee to discuss the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales.
2. The meeting was being broadcast live on Senedd.tv, with all participants joining via video conference, and was bilingual with simultaneous translation from Welsh to English.
3. The meeting was conducted in accordance with all Standing Order requirements for committees, with the exception of procedural adaptations for remote proceedings.
4. The Minister expressed gratitude to all those who have been working hard to keep schools open for the children of key workers and vulnerable children.
5. She emphasized that the health and well-being of children, young people, and staff in education settings is her primary concern.
6. Hefin David AM asked about the Minister's five principles regarding when schools might reopen, to which the Minister replied that schools will move to a new phase when it is safe to do so, based on advice from the Chief Medical Officer and the Chief Scientific Officer.
7. She also mentioned that a return to normal is not imminent and that there are practical issues to consider before schools can reopen, such as social distancing, school transport, and avoiding gatherings at the school gate.
8. Sian Gwenllian AM asked about the importance of testing in the next phase of education, to which the Minister replied that testing, tracing, and quarantine will be crucial in the next phase of the Government's response to the pandemic.
9. Dawn Bowden AM asked about the arrangements for children of key workers and vulnerable children attending school hubs, to which the Minister replied that there has been a doubling in the number of children attending school hubs in the last week, with 85% being vulnerable children.
10. The Minister also mentioned that schools are working with local authorities to risk assess children and young people with a social worker and to support them in various ways, including having conversations about some of those children attending the hubs.

The discussion focuses on making it clear to parents that the legislation is not trying to criminalize them, with witnesses emphasizing the importance of upholding the rights of the child and the need for clarity in the law. They also discuss the impact of physical punishment on children and the importance of simplicity and clarity in the Bill.

The project team is discussing the design of a remote control, including the number and type of buttons, the use of a scroll wheel, and the cost of production. They are trying to balance functionality, usability, and cost to create a product that will appeal to their target market while staying within budget. Marketing expresses discontent with the changes made to the button design, but the team agrees to continue with the current design for further evaluation.

The group discussed the final design of a product and evaluated its look-and-feel, usability, and interface design. They also discussed the product evaluation and the finance, ensuring that everything fits within their budget of twelve and a half Euros per remote. They had some concerns about keeping the design simple while also meeting all the necessary functions. They also discussed the possibility of using a scroll wheel to save space and reduce the number of buttons.

Alastair Birch, a representative of the Association of Directors of Education Wales, expressed confidence that the Bill would uphold the rights of the child, as the current legislation has been criticized for still allowing the defense of reasonable punishment. He mentioned that ADEW will always advocate for the rights of the child to be upheld, and that the express opinions of the child and the voice of the child are a fundamental aspect of any safe environment.

In this meeting, the team discussed the prototype for a new remote control design. The prototype is a hand-held, curved device with big, easy-to-use buttons and a logo imprinted on it. It is made of plastic with a rubber casing and is powered by kinetic energy. The team also evaluated the prototype based on user requirements and hot trends, and found that it is easy to use, trendy, and has good buttons, but is not particularly technologically innovative. Overall, the team was satisfied with the prototype and the project process.

Marketing, Industrial Design, and Project Management are discussing the design and evaluation of a product, specifically a remote control. They are considering factors such as budget, features, and target demographic. They ultimately decide on a design with seven buttons and no LCD screen, which fits within their budget of twelve Euros and fifty cents.

The group is discussing the transcription of audio data for speech recognition research. They are considering how to handle breaths and other non-speech sounds in the transcripts. One suggestion is to automatically detect breaths and other non-speech sounds and mark them in the transcripts. Another suggestion is to have transcribers manually mark these sounds, but only within chunks of speech that contain words. The group agrees that it is important to mark these non-speech sounds in some way, as they can affect the performance of speech recognition systems. They also discuss the possibility of using scripts to process the master transcripts in different ways for different research purposes. The group will continue to consider the best approach for handling breaths and other non-speech sounds in the transcripts.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee discussed awareness raising for the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill. Witnesses included Sally Jenkins, chair of All Wales Heads of Children's Services; Alastair Birch, senior system leader for equalities and safeguarding at Pembrokeshire County Council; and Councillor Huw David, Welsh Local Government Association spokesperson for health and social care. They expressed general support for the Bill, stating that current legislation is ineffective and unclear in protecting children's rights. They emphasized the importance of educating children about their rights and involving families in the implementation process. The witnesses also discussed potential unintended consequences and the importance of resources for successful implementation. The committee also questioned the witnesses on the impact of the Bill on social services, education, and resources.

Industrial Designer introduced two prototypes of a remote control, one with a conventional layout of buttons and another with a surfboard shape and six keys that perform the job of twelve keys. The team discussed the look, feel, innovation, ease of use, target demographic, trends, and cost of both prototypes, and ultimately decided to move forward with the surfboard-shaped remote control with seven buttons, excluding the LCD screen and speech recognition feature due to budget constraints.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a scrutiny session on the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill. The witnesses were Sally Jenkins, chair of All Wales Heads of Children's Services; Alastair Birch, senior system leader for equalities and safeguarding at Pembrokeshire County Council; and Councillor Huw David, Welsh Local Government Association spokesperson for health and social care. They were asked about their general support for the Bill and its potential impact on children and families. The witnesses expressed their support for the Bill, stating that it would bring clarity and improve the rights of the child. They also discussed the evidence provided by social services regarding the harmful effects of physical punishment and the need for greater clarity around the definition of corporal punishment. The witnesses also mentioned the importance of awareness raising and resources for the implementation of the Bill.

The project manager and team are having a meeting to discuss the final design of their product and evaluate the project. They are evaluating the design and usability interface, and discussing the finance and project evaluation. The team is concerned about keeping the design simple and fitting within their budget of twelve and a half Euros per remote.

The Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill aims to change the current legislation to uphold the rights of the child as per the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. The Association of Directors of Social Services (ADSS), Association of Directors of Education Wales (ADEW), and the Welsh Local Government Association (WLGA) support the Bill, citing the need to clarify the current ambiguity in how children are treated and cared for. Social services and education professionals have been involved in the consultation process for the Bill and will continue to be involved in its implementation. The Bill is not expected to have a major impact on social services' capacity to deal with it, but further work is needed to determine the cost implications for all agencies involved. The Bill does not undermine existing local authority responsibilities, but rather reinforces the state's role in protecting children from harm. The WLGA emphasizes the importance of making sure that resources are made available for the successful implementation of the Bill.

The team discussed the cost of the product, specifically the price of the main designer's involvement and the budget of twelve Euros and fifty cents. They also talked about the design of two items, one of which is a basic remote control for eight Euros and the other is a more advanced model with additional features for sixteen Euros. The team considered the possibility of adding speech recognition to the advanced model, but ultimately decided against it due to budget constraints. They also discussed the importance of the LCD display and the number of buttons, ultimately deciding to prioritize functionality and ease of use over having an LCD display.

The group discussed the design of a new remote control, deciding on a minimal design with a small joystick, LCD, and a few buttons. They also discussed using a rubber or plastic case, and the possibility of using a kinetic or solar-powered battery. The group also talked about the conceptual design phase, including deciding on the materials and components to be used.

During a project meeting, the team discusses the final design of a remote control. The design includes various buttons for different functions, including volume, channel, mute, help, and teletext. The team debates whether all the buttons are necessary, considering the budget of twelve and a half Euros per remote. They also discuss the possibility of integrating certain functions to save on costs. The project manager raises concerns about the complexity of the design, suggesting that it may be too complicated for the intended users, who are older people. The team also discusses the possibility of using a scroll wheel instead of individual buttons for channel and volume control. They consider the advantages and disadvantages of this approach, including the potential cost savings and the usability for older people. Ultimately, they decide to continue with the current design, but to explore the possibility of using a scroll wheel in future designs. The team also discusses the importance of marketing and advertising to ensure that the remote is well-received by the target audience.

The team discussed the design of a remote control, deciding that it should be universal, modern, fun, different, sturdy, easy to find with a locator function, and one-handed. They also discussed potential shapes, including a ball-shaped phone and a keyboard shape, and considered user feedback that indicated a desire for fewer buttons and a tracking device. The team also discussed the possibility of incorporating speech recognition technology, but ultimately decided against it due to potential language and dialect barriers and the risk of it becoming a gimmick.

The project manager and team are discussing the design of a new remote control with a minimal design featuring a small joystick, LCD, and a few buttons. They are considering using a rubber or plastic case, and are discussing the use of conventional batteries versus alternative options like kinetic or solar-powered batteries. The team is also discussing the possibility of using an LCD and the potential costs associated with it.

The Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill aims to change the current law to remove the defense of reasonable punishment in Wales. The witnesses, Sally Jenkins, Alastair Birch, and Huw David, support the Bill and believe that the current law is ineffective and unclear. They state that the rights of the child should be upheld and that the best interests of the child should be the priority. The witnesses also mention that physical punishment can be emotionally damaging for children and that it can potentially lead to more serious physical or sexual abuse. They emphasize the need for greater clarity around the definition of corporal punishment, but not necessarily on the face of the Bill. The witnesses also discuss the implementation of the Bill and the importance of awareness raising and training for professionals. They mention that the impact on other services, like housing and education, should be considered. The witnesses also discuss the rise in the number of looked-after children in Wales and the pressures on local authorities, but they believe that the Bill will not have a major impact on their capacity to deal with it. They also mention that the state has a responsibility to protect children from harm and that children can be raised without the use of physical punishment. The witnesses do not foresee any unintended consequences for the Bill if implemented carefully and with the right resources.

The user interface designer, industrial designer, and marketing representative discussed the detailed design of a product with the project manager. They evaluated the product's features, such as the cradle, scroll wheel, and favorite channels function. The production cost was estimated to be fifteen point eight Euros, and the team discussed the possibility of adding a trigger button. The team was generally positive about the product and its marketability.

In a meeting, the project manager, marketing expert, user interface designer, and industrial designer discuss the views from the last meeting review and market research regarding the development of a new remote. They discuss the desire for the remote to be modern, fun, different, sturdy, easy to find, and possibly ball-shaped or keyboard-shaped, and to be usable with one hand. The marketing expert presents research on what users want in a remote, including a modern appearance, multifunctionality, simplification, and reduced number of buttons, and possibly speech recognition. The industrial designer discusses the technical functions of a remote and suggests focusing on a universal TV remote with a user-centered design, fewer buttons, and possibly a hidden button interface.

In a meeting, the team discussed the design of a remote control with a spongey, fruity aesthetic, and a kinetic energy source. They also considered using an advanced chip, a double curved case made of rubber, and a user interface with pushbuttons and scroll buttons for menus. The team aimed to appeal to a young, dynamic target group while keeping the product safe and long-lasting.

The team discussed the detailed design of a product, including its presentation, evaluation, finance, and closing remarks. The product's estimated production cost is 15.8 Euros per unit, and it includes features such as TV functions, a locator, a scroll wheel, and a favorites list. The team also discussed the product's color scheme, which will be determined by the marketing team. The product's price range is expected to be between 35 to 50 Euros, and the team is considering making it upgradable in the future. The team also discussed the meeting room setup and the use of lapel microphones, which they found uncomfortable.

Professor D summarizes a meeting about speech recognition research, discussing results from Stephane, Sunil, and the ICSI OGI system. He mentions that the results show improvement in some cases but not in others, and there are still issues with the Danish data. The group plans to continue working on the problem and will meet again in two weeks to discuss their findings.

The project manager summarizes the last meeting's decisions, which included a minimal design with a small joystick, LCD, and a few buttons. The remote control's shape will be adventurous due to the minimal design and will include a locating transmitter. The meeting's focus is the conceptual design phase, covering parts' materials and construction. The industrial designer presents concepts for the case material, including plastic, rubber, titanium, or wood. They discuss battery options, settling on conventional batteries for cost and off-the-shelf availability. The team considers single or double curved shapes for the remote, with titanium being lightweight but expensive. The user interface designer will work on the menu structure and button functionality, considering trade-offs for scroll wheel and LCD use. The team will also look into the costs of components and potential chip requirements for an LCD.

In a kick-off meeting, the team discussed designing a new user-friendly remote control. They started by drawing their favorite animals and discussing their favorite characteristics, which included fish, cats, badgers, and giraffes. The remote control is intended to be multifunctional, covering different variances in signals for sound systems, TVs, DVD players, VHS players, and TiVo. The team also discussed the importance of the remote's design, battery type, and size, as well as its functionality and user requirements.

In a kick-off meeting, the team discussed designing a new, original, trendy, and user-friendly remote control. The process involves individual work on functional and conceptual design, followed by detailed design. The team drew their favorite animals and shared their characteristics, which led to a discussion about making the remote multifunctional, user-friendly, ergonomic, and high-tech. The team also briefly talked about battery types, size, and meeting tasks for individual team members.

The project manager of a product development team is summarizing a meeting about creating a new universal remote control. The team is discussing the design, user interface, and functionality of the remote. They consider including a scroll wheel, back-lit buttons, and a cradle for charging and syncing with the television. They also discuss the possibility of a radio transmitter and locator feature. The team is considering positioning the remote in the mid to higher-end market range. They aim to sell the remote for thirty-five to fifty Euros and need to determine the cost of production. The next step is for the design and technology team to come up with a design proposal and cost estimate.

In a meeting, the group discussed the function of rolling through channels on a universal remote control. The project manager and industrial designer will present their concepts and ideas in a conceptual design meeting. The remote control will have a plastic inner shell and a rubber outer shell for durability. The user interface will have push buttons, a scroll wheel with an integrated push button, and an LCD display as options. The remote control will use a simple chip, regular chip, or advanced chip for operation. The group also discussed the possibility of a speech recognition feature, but decided against it due to potential interference from the TV. The remote control will have a cradle for charging and as a marketing standard. The group aims to make the product unique and special to increase its marketability.

The project manager announces changes from higher management, revealing that the new remote controls are for a specific television and not all-in-one as previously thought. Marketing presents market potential research, finding that consumers prefer good-looking remote controls and are willing to pay more for them, and that speech recognition is unpopular with younger age groups.

In a meeting, the team discussed the prototype of a new product. The prototype is a remote control made of edible Play-Doh, designed to be ergonomic, easy to use, and innovative. The remote is double curved, with buttons designed for each finger, and a special lock and mute button. The team is considering making left-handed and right-handed versions of the remote. The remote is also conformable to the size of the user's hand. The team is pleased with the prototype and believes it meets their expectations. The project manager mentions that the costs for the prototype are within budget, at ten Euro seventy cents per unit. The team is satisfied with their work and believes the product will be successful. The meeting is then adjourned.

In a meeting, the team discussed the functional design of a remote control. They had not yet decided if it should be universal or specific. The project manager suggested giving individual actions for each member, such as the Industrial Designer working on the working design and the User Interface (UI) guy working on the interface. The marketing expert was supposed to deliver specifications. They also discussed giving the project a name, and considered "Mando" as a possibility. The UI suggested incorporating new technologies and making the remote control more stylish, while the marketing expert focused on improving the user experience and addressing issues such as the RSI disease. The industrial designer suggested making the remote control suitable for both right and left-handed people. The team also discussed the possibility of incorporating a LCD or speech recognition system, but had concerns about the budget. The project manager then introduced new requirements from the head office, including restricting the remote control to TVs and focusing on internet aspects. The corporate image should also be clearly identified in the product. The UI suggested using a mouse or scroll wheel for changing channels, and the industrial designer suggested having finger molds for a better grip. The team also discussed the price point and target market for the remote control.

The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has been involved in the Welsh Government's school improvement journey and will publish a report on Welsh education in March 2020. The School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2

The Welsh Government has involved the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) in the school improvement journey, with the OECD set to publish a report on Welsh education in March 2020. The School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2

The Welsh Government has involved the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) in the school improvement journey, with the OECD set to publish a report on Welsh education in March 2020. The School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2

The Welsh Government has involved the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) in a review of the Welsh education system, with the latest report expected to be published in March 2020. The School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2013 gives local authorities powers to intervene in schools, but the use of these powers has been mixed. The national evaluation and improvement resource is being developed to promote self-evaluation in schools and improve standards.

The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has been involved in the Welsh Government's school improvement journey, providing reviews and feedback on the state of Welsh education. The Welsh Government has used the School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2013 to intervene in schools facing challenges, with local authorities having the power to appoint additional governors, suspend delegated budgets, or replace governing bodies. The national evaluation and improvement resource is being developed to promote self-evaluation in schools, with the aim of improving skills and building a more robust approach to self-evaluation. The resource is being tested and evaluated, with the intention of introducing it across the system in September 2020.

In the episode "The Secret in the Soil" of the TV show Bones, agents Seeley Booth and Temperance Brennan are sent to a therapist, Dr. Lance Sweets, after Booth arrests Brennan's father. Booth and Brennan are tasked with solving the murder of Franklin Curtis, an organic food entrepreneur who was found cooked on an abandoned farm. The investigation leads them to suspect Andrew Harding, the owner of the farm, but they eventually discover that Franklin's daughter Kat is the killer. Kat killed Franklin's mistress Emma, who was also her half-sister, and then killed Franklin when he found out. Booth and Brennan also have to deal with their own relationship dynamics and their feelings about the case as they work together to solve it.

The team is discussing the design of a remote control for a specific television. They are considering the use of speech recognition, but realize it may not be practical due to noise interference. They also discuss the importance of making the remote control look good, as many users find existing remotes to be ugly. The marketing expert, Rajan, has conducted a market survey and found that 75% of users find existing remotes to be ugly, and 80% of users are willing to pay more for a good-looking remote control. They also discuss the importance of making the remote control easy to use, with only the necessary buttons. The user interface designer suggests using a more organic shape and a rubbery material to make the remote control more durable and ergonomic. They also consider adding a glow-in-the-dark feature to help users find the remote control in the dark. The industrial designer mentions that they have done research on speech recognition and whistling, and wonders if many people can actually whistle. The team also discusses the possibility of using a noise detection feature to help users find the remote control when it is lost.

The project manager announces changes from higher up that the new remote controls are for a specific television, not all-in-one. The team will adapt their existing work to fit this new requirement. Marketing has conducted a market survey and found that consumers dislike the current remote controls' appearance and want a good-looking design. They also found that consumers only use a small percentage of the buttons on remote controls, so simplicity and ease of use are important. The industrial designer will take these factors into account when designing the new remote controls. The team also discusses the possibility of adding speech recognition or noise detection features to help users find the remote control when it's lost. The remote controls will have a trendy and fashionable design, with an organic shape and simple buttons. The industrial designer will create a prototype using existing corporate designs as inspiration. The remote controls will have a simple user interface, with programmable options for users to customize their experience. The team will also consider adding a glow-in-the-dark feature to help users locate the remote control in the dark. The remote controls will use regular batteries and have a basic transmission interface. The team will aim to keep costs down while still delivering a high-quality product.

The scene opens with two men being abducted in Berlin, and the CIA suspects it's the work of a Russian nationalist group called The Covenant. The group demands the release of Arvin Sloane in exchange for the remaining agent. Jack Bristow, Sydney's father, investigates Sydney's disappearance and meets with Sloane, who provides him with a disc containing leads on her whereabouts. Sydney, who has lost the last two years of her memory, is determined to act normal and goes on a mission to retrieve a package for The Covenant. However, she finds the severed head of the younger agent instead. The CIA agrees to trade Sloane for their remaining agent, and Sydney and Weiss are sent to Mexico for the exchange. The exchange goes awry when Delta Force, acting on orders from the National Security Council, shows up and a shootout ensues. The Covenant escapes with both Sark and Rotter, and Lindsay, the Director of the National Security Council, reveals to Sydney that he used her and her team as bait.

The Welsh Government has involved the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) in the school improvement journey, with the OECD conducting a rapid review of Welsh education at the beginning of the Assembly term and scheduled to publish a report in March 2020. The School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2013 gives local authorities powers to intervene in schools, and the Welsh Government encourages local authorities to take a proactive approach. The national evaluation and improvement resource is being developed to promote self-evaluation in schools, with the aim of improving the system as a whole. The resource is being tested and is expected to be introduced across the system in September 2020. The investment in school standards has been significant in this Assembly term, with 50% of the money going towards professional learning for staff. The categorization system is used to identify schools that need support, and the Welsh Government is working to improve the system to better align it with curriculum reform and self-evaluation. The Chief Inspector has raised concerns about schools not being identified early enough, and the Welsh Government is working to address this issue through the use of data and a new multi-agency approach for schools causing concern.

The Welsh Government has involved the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) in the school improvement journey, with the OECD providing reviews and feedback on the state of Welsh education. The School Standards and Organization (Wales) Act 2013 gives local authorities the power to intervene in schools if necessary, and the Welsh Government encourages local authorities to take a proactive approach to intervention. The national evaluation and improvement resource is being developed to promote self-evaluation in the school system, with the aim of making progress in Welsh education by developing skills within the system. Investment in school standards has been significant in this Assembly term, with 50% of the money going towards professional learning for teaching professionals. The school categorization system is used to identify schools that need support or challenge, with categorization evolving over time to include professional judgments from challenge advisers. The Estyn inspection system is separate from the categorization system and is used for accountability purposes. The Welsh Government is working to identify schools that need support earlier and is piloting a new multi-agency approach to support improvement in those schools. The categorization system has been effective in identifying schools that need support, but there is still work to be done in moving those schools more quickly to see improvement, particularly in the secondary sector. The Welsh Government is also working to improve the way data is shared and used to identify schools that need support earlier.

George and Callie struggle with the aftermath of George's mistake, while Meredith and Derek discuss their relationship. Meanwhile, the hospital staff deals with various medical cases, including a young woman with osteoporosis and a football player who needs spinal surgery. Throughout the day, the characters navigate difficult conversations, emotional moments, and professional challenges.

Frasier has a crush on his coworker Kate, but denies it until Roz points out his "goofy little teenage look." Kate announces she's leaving for a job in Chicago, and Frasier realizes he has feelings for her. He rushes to the airport to tell her, but finds she already has a date. After some confusion, Frasier and Kate declare their love for each other, but Kate's flight is delayed and Frasier has to work. They part ways, realizing they have many differences and may not be compatible.

In this episode of "Friends," Rachel discovers that she and Ross are still married due to Ross not obtaining an annulment. Ross confesses that he didn't want to face another failed marriage. Joey finds keys to a Porsche and pretends to own it, leading to a conversation with a woman about the car. Rachel and Phoebe discuss living together since Denise is leaving town. Rachel and Ross fill out annulment papers, but their reasons for the annulment are false. Chandler, Monica, and Phoebe babysit Frank and Alice's triplets, leading to an assembly line for diaper changes. Joey washes the "Porsche" and talks to a guy about the car, but the car belongs to someone else.

Terri, a character on the show Degrassi, is feeling insecure about her weight and thinks that boys won't notice her. Her father tries to reassure her, but Terri still doesn't believe him. Spinner, a popular boy at school, asks Terri for notes and later asks her if she's going to the dance. Terri says she can't go because of her father, but Ashley thinks that Terri is lying. It is later revealed that Terri doesn't want to go to the dance because she doesn't think anyone will want to dance with her. Ashley and Paige help Terri get ready for the dance and Terri expresses her interest in Spinner. At the dance, Terri is drunk and makes a scene, causing Ashley to intervene. Terri dances with Spinner, but later gets sick in the bathroom. The next day at school, Terri is embarrassed about what happened at the dance. She talks to Ashley and Spinner comes up to them to return the notes. Paige tells Spinner that she will be the one providing him with notes from now on, leaving Terri looking sad.

Lorelai and Rory are discussing wedding dress shopping and Rory suggests going to a bridal store to try on real veils, but Lorelai is hesitant due to her negative experiences with taffeta and bustles in the past. Meanwhile, at Chilton, Rory is talking with Paris, Madeline, and Louise about summer school and overhears Paris talking about a Rebuilding Together event. Paris tries to convince Rory not to go, but Rory is determined. Later, Lorelai tells Emily about her plans to help build a house for charity and Emily seems uninterested.

The episode of Frasier originally featured a subplot about Daphne trying to expand her physical therapy clientele, but it was later cut. In this episode, Frasier and Niles become obsessed with getting into the gold level of a luxury spa, but are repeatedly denied access. Roz, a friend of Frasier and Niles, offers to help them get in by calling a senator she knows. However, when they learn that Roz had a romantic relationship with the senator, they become uncomfortable and decide to find another way in. In the end, their attempts to sneak into the gold level lead them to an alley behind the spa, where they are surrounded by garbage and bees. Meanwhile, Martin is compared to the father on the show Rockford and takes offense to it.

Phoebe is at the bar and suggests getting Sean another drink, even though it's over the club limit. Piper joins them and they discuss Prue's absence and suspect she might be preoccupied with work. The topic of Leo's absence and the possibility of the Elders watching him comes up. Prue calls, saying she's on her way home from work and shares her discovery of Micah's ancestors, hoping it will help identify the demon sent to kill them. Prue arrives home to find the front door open and all the mirrors broken. Darryl investigates and finds fingerprints, but they don't match any known criminals. The sisters create a grudge list of past and present enemies, and Prue mentions the triad. Darryl suggests it could be a human stalker, but Prue is convinced it's the triad. Upstairs, they find the Book of Shadows door unlocked, which concerns Prue. Leo orbs in, and Prue questions him about the triad. Phoebe suggests they need to "get Prue laid," and Leo and Piper share a moment. Prue becomes increasingly fixated on the triad and the demon they sent to kill them. Troxa, the demon, appears and attacks Prue, but she manages to use her power and send him flying through a window. The sisters suspect a human stalker, but Prue is convinced it's the triad. Darryl suggests they get an alarm system, but Prue dismisses the idea. Prue goes to the attic to research mirrors and finds her pillow hovering above her face. She becomes convinced a demon is after her and sets a trap to catch it.

Ty has taken a job at a wildlife reserve and is dealing with poachers who are threatening the animals there. Amy is helping train a skittish horse named Dash and is trying to figure out why he won't stand still. Jade, a friend of Lou's daughter, is staying at Heartland for a few days and is not happy about having to help out with chores around the ranch. Bob, the owner of the wildlife reserve, has had run-ins with poachers in the past and is hesitant to get the authorities involved.

Sheldon and Amy are recording the final episode of their flag-themed internet show, Fun with Flags. Leonard, Howard, and Raj are cleaning out the office of a deceased professor and discover his food diary, which they initially mistake for important research. LeVar Burton appears as a guest on Fun with Flags and is unimpressed with Sheldon's portrayal of George Washington Carver. Professor Sharpe, the professor's former office mate, reveals that his research never amounted to anything. Bernadette learns that her colleagues are intimidated by her and tries to be more sensitive, but ends up accidentally revealing that she has been using the company's swear jar money to pay for her private bathroom.

Casey and Ashleigh are preparing for a slumber party at their sorority, ZBZ house. Casey is using the opportunity to impress the pledges and win their votes for the upcoming Zeta Beta President election. Rebecca, another sister, hijacks the party by telling ghost stories. The sisters believe that the ghost of a former ZBZ member, Virginia, is haunting the house. Meanwhile, at the KT house, Cappie is trying to impress a girl named Destiny, who seems to have a hidden agenda. Rusty becomes suspicious of Destiny and discovers that her real name is Patty, a girl Cappie knew from camp ten years ago. Patty had a crush on Cappie back then and has gone through great lengths to see him again. At the Omega Chi house, Evan and Calvin are dealing with a mouse infestation and share a moment when they realize they both love horror movies. Back at the ZBZ house, the sisters conduct a séance to communicate with Virginia's ghost and discover that the election was fixed, and Virginia actually won. Casey admits to fixing the election, but the sisters decide to redo the election, and Casey wins unanimously. The night ends with Casey, Ashleigh, and Jen sharing ice cream and discussing the night's events.

Sheldon is drawing a hypothetical containment field for a wormhole on a napkin, which Howard dismisses as a doodle. Leonard brings up the idea that making contact with other life-forms might not end well for humanity. Sheldon then challenges Howard to build the containment field, but Howard is skeptical. The group then becomes curious about Sheldon's daily disappearance at 2:45 pm, and they decide to follow him to see where he goes. Meanwhile, Penny is texting with a guy she met at school, and Leonard becomes jealous and insecure. Sheldon later admits to Leonard that he uses the basement room to recharge and that the number 43 has something to do with his secret project. In the end, it is revealed that Sheldon uses the room to practice juggling with a beanbag, and the number 43 is just a number he can't seem to reach during his juggling practice.

J.R. tells Tad about his father dangling 50 million dollars in front of him in exchange for being his son. Babe confesses to Krystal that she kissed Richie Novak after finding out about his potential bone marrow transplant. Colby finds out that Dre is related to Senator Samuel Woods and is hiding from his father's political family business. Hannah takes Josh hostage and shoots at Zach when he tries to intervene. Babe invites J.R. to stay at her place for the night after having a bad nightmare. Annie and Ryan joke around in the hospital room after he wakes up from his surgery.

Veronica and Mac are hired by a genetically altered capuchin monkey's researchers to find it after it was stolen. They suspect the animal rights group PHAT (People for Humane Animal Treatment) is responsible. Veronica and Mac attend a PHAT meeting and learn about the group's letter-writing campaign. Veronica suspects there might be a splinter cell within PHAT and sets up a plan to get inside. Meanwhile, Keith is investigating the suicide of Hearst College Dean O'Dell and suspects his wife, Mindy, may be involved due to her infidelity. He questions Weevil, who found the body, and learns about a note left on the computer. Veronica helps Keith by sharing her criminology project, where she planned a fake suicide with a clichéd note left on the computer.

Dr. Sinclair reveals to Aidan that Annie tampered with Greenlee's motorcycle, causing her crash; Zach and Kendall argue over his role in Greenlee's disappearance, with Kendall believing it's her fault; Ryan is determined to keep searching for Greenlee despite the dangerous weather and Jesse's warnings.

In the underworld, Cole is shocked to find himself standing before the Source, who is actually his future self after having absorbed the Source's powers. The Source explains that they are now one and that he is reborn within Cole. Cole is determined to fight the Source within him and refuses to let it hurt Phoebe. The Source stabs him, and Cole wakes up from this dream, frightened. He looks over at Phoebe, who is sleeping. Meanwhile, Piper has prepared a celebration meal for the sisters, but Paige orbs in, saying she has been practicing orbing. They are all excited about this new development in her powers. Phoebe enters the room, looking for coffee, and mentions that she has a bad feeling about Cole. Piper dismisses it as cold feet, but Phoebe is not convinced. In the underworld, the Source appears to Cole, who is confused about how he got there. The Source explains that his magic brought him there and that he must accept his fate as the new Source. The Source tells Cole that he and the Seer must stop Kurzon, an underworld demon who will attempt to fill the power vacuum left by the Source's death. Cole is reluctant to follow the Source's bidding, but the Source threatens to use his powers to force Cole to comply. Back in the manor, Phoebe is worried about Cole and casts a spell to help her listen to her heart's desire. As a result, her past and future selves appear to her. Her past self is frightened and confused, while her future self is bitter and angry. Phoebe's future self refuses to answer any questions about Cole, saying that the consequences of changing the future are too great. Phoebe is frustrated and sends her future self back to her own time. In the underworld, the Seer tells Kurzon that he must kill Phoebe's past self, who has been conjured by Phoebe's spell, in order to destroy the Charmed Ones. Kurzon attacks the manor, and Cole manages to save Phoebe's past self from him. After Kurzon disappears, Cole tells the sisters that they can use Kurzon's blood to scry for him and vanquish him. Phoebe goes to try to talk some sense into her future self, while Piper, Paige, and Cole work on finding and

In the Salvatore boarding house, Damon struggles to write a eulogy for Liz Forbes, while Caroline, Elena, Matt, Tyler, and Stefan work together to prepare for her funeral. Meanwhile, in the 1994 prison world, Bonnie finally regains her magic and plans to use the eclipse to return home. However, she finds herself in a different prison world - the Salvatore boarding house in 1903. Back in the present day, Jo discovers that she is pregnant with Kai's baby, and he manipulates her into giving him her magic to save both of their lives. At the funeral, Damon delivers a heartfelt eulogy for Liz, and Caroline struggles to hold herself together. Later that night, Elena confronts Caroline about her plan to turn off her humanity, but Caroline ultimately snaps her neck in anger. Bonnie returns from the prison world and reunites with Damon, while Stefan discovers Elena's unconscious body in Caroline's house. Damon realizes that the woman Bonnie encountered in the 1903 prison world is his own mother.

Kendall is torn between her love for Zach and her growing feelings for Ryan, while David is determined to gain custody of his grandson and is not afraid to use threats to achieve his goal. Meanwhile, J.R. is in jail and Little A has been taken into foster care, and Jesse and Angie decide to take the boy in.

Amanda and J.R. share a room and discuss J.R.'s desire to be near her. Bianca walks in on her mother and Reese, who are preparing for the wedding. Reese wakes up with a hangover and discusses her regrets with Kendall. Aidan tells Annie about Dr. Sinclair's motives and tries to convince her to get help. Ryan and Greenlee decide to postpone their wedding due to Greenlee's illness. Tad and Jake discuss J.R. and Amanda's relationship, and J.R. reveals that Amanda is pregnant. Erica and Reese discuss the wedding plans and Bianca's move. Ryan and Jack discuss the wedding, and Opal shares her dream about Greenlee's wedding day. Greenlee leaves the inn on her motorcycle, and Ryan follows her. Kendall becomes upset when she learns that Reese and Bianca are staying in Pine Valley. Annie takes Aidan's gun and watches as Greenlee leaves on her motorcycle.

Sheldon is upset because his new wallet doesn't have as much space as he thought it would. Raj's parents, who are in India, video chat with him and the gang. They want Raj to marry a woman named Lalita Gupta, whom he doesn't know. Raj is anxious about this, as he has trouble talking to women. Sheldon suggests that Raj should go through with the arranged marriage, comparing it to the way things were done in the past. Later, Raj finds out that Lalita has been trying to call him. He enlists Howard's help in calling her back, and Howard pretends to be Raj. Raj then goes to Penny's apartment to drink and complain about his situation. Penny, who is practicing making drinks for a new bartending job, gives him a grasshopper. Raj gets drunk and decides to tell his parents that he won't go through with the arranged marriage. Penny convinces him to meet Lalita first and see what happens. When they meet, Raj is surprised to find that Lalita is not fat anymore. He had known her when they were younger, and he used to tease her about her weight. Sheldon comes to the restaurant and is shocked to see that Lalita looks like a character from a children's storybook that his mother used to read to him when he was sick. He becomes infatuated with her, much to Raj's annoyance. Lalita, who is a dentist, takes a liking to Sheldon and invites him to join her and Raj for dinner.

Simone tells Joni that she shouldn't get involved in a plan to break into the school. Mia wants to know why Jake left her. Liza reveals to Adam that she kissed Tad. Jamie and Adam argue about JR's whereabouts, with Adam accusing Jamie of hiding JR due to jealousy. Doug refuses to sign Laurie's financial aid forms for college. Tad and Lysistrata continue to spar with each other, both as therapist and potential date. Mia confronts Alison about her relationship with Jake. Joni tries to help Simone break into the school. Doug and Laurie have a heated argument about her desire to go to college.

Tad finds out that Krystal is getting married to David and asks her why. She says it's because she loves David. Tad tries to understand and asks if David got her pregnant, but Krystal denies it. Meanwhile, Adam and Erica discuss Amanda's sudden departure from Fusion. Adam reveals that Amanda was asked to sign over custody of her unborn child to J.R., which led to her outburst and quitting the company. Jake brings Amanda to a diner after she starts spotting. He suggests they get another A for their plan, referring to Amanda's unborn child. At Fusion, David and Krystal get married. David says they deserve to be happy and promises that they will be. J.R. is seen drinking alone, inhaling sharply as he downs another bottle of alcohol.

In "How I Met Your Mother," Ted's daughter wants to hear a story about happily ever after, but her father reveals that not all stories end that way. The story starts in 2005 when Ted puts on a green and brown shirt that he has had for six years but suddenly likes. His friends comment on the shirt, and the conversation turns to Ted's past relationships. Lily suggests that Ted should consider getting back together with Steph, a former girlfriend who worked in the porn industry. Marshall suggests Jackie, another ex-girlfriend who once hit a hitchhiker while driving. However, Ted is thinking about Natalie, a girl he has fond memories of, including her sock monkey collection and her love for Belle and Sebastian.
